questions.text: Metrorrhagia refers to _______

choices.text: Regularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on abnormal cyclical bleeding
Regularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on abnormal cyclical bleeding
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding

questions.solution:
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding are referred to as metrorrhagia.

Menstrual cycle irregularities are as follows:

  • Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs irregularly and at frequent intervals.
  • Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding occurring at intervals of more than 35 days.
  • Amenorrhea indicates the absence of menstruation. 
  • Polymenorrhea indicates frequent episodes of menstruation that occur at intervals of 21 days or lesser. 
  • Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>5 days). 
  • Intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding (usually not excessive) that occurs between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
  • Precocious menstruation is the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
  • Postcoital bleeding is vaginal bleeding after sexual intercourse.

questions.text: What percentage of platelets does the spleen normally sequester?
questions.solution: The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Flagellate dermatitis is caused by _____.
questions.solution:
Flagellate dermatitis is caused by bleomycin.

Flagellate erythema/ dermatitis is characterized by multiple red, macular streaks of erythema on the trunk and limbs. The streaks are aligned in a criss‐cross pattern, giving a whip-like or flagellate appearance. They may be sore or pruritic. 

Flagellate erythema is seen in

  • A side effect of bleomycin chemotherapy
  • The toxic effect after consumption of shitake mushrooms
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Adult-onset Still’s disease
  • Docetaxel therapy

It is self-limiting and usually resolves within a few days to weeks. Topical steroids and oral antihistamines can be given to relieve the associated pruritis.

questions.text: Which is the most common fracture associated with acute compartment syndrome in adult patients?
questions.solution:
The most common fracture causing acute compartment syndrome in adult patients is tibial diaphyseal fractures.

Fractures are the most common cause for acute compartment syndrome. The top 3 fracture sites associated with acute compartment syndrome include:

  • Tibial diaphysis (shaft) 
  • Distal radius
  • Forearm bones diaphysis

Soft tissue injury is the second most common cause of acute compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following gland secretes lingual lipase?
questions.solution:
Lingual lipase is secreted by von Ebner’s gland.

von Ebner's gland is a serous salivary gland situated around circumvallate and foliate papillae in front of the terminal sulcus. 

Lingual lipase hydrolyse dietary lipid. The optimal pH is 3-6. Unlike pancreatic lipase, it is not inhibited by bile salts, medium-chain FA, and lecithin. Hence, it remains active through the stomach and into the intestine.

questions.text: A 68- year-old patient presents with difficulty in initiating micturition. A DRE reveals an enlarged nodular prostate with adherent rectal mucosa. PSA was found to be 25 ng/ml and a biopsy result was suggestive of adenocarcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition ?

choices.text: PSA is a not specific marker for the condition.
Gleason score correlates with the pathological stage
It is associated with decreased % free PSA
It arises from the transitional zone of the gland.

questions.solution:
Prostatic carcinoma, as indicated in the clinical scenario, arises from the peripheral zone of the gland.

Anatomically, the prostate is divided into three zones. 

  • The peripheral zone lies posteriorly and has an abundance of prostatic glands. 
  • The central zone lies posterior to the urethral lumen and above the seminal vesicles as they course through the prostate. 
  • The transitional zone is periurethral.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia arises from the transitional zone.

Gleason grading may be used after biopsy to evaluate the stage of histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is high risk.

PSA (prostatic specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH.

Slightly elevated total PSA (between 4.0 and 10.0 ng/mL) and low free PSA (<25%) is suspicious for prostate cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a simple asphyxiant?
questions.solution:
Helium is classified as a simple asphyxiant.

An asphyxiant is a toxic or non-toxic gas which causes respiratory embarrassment and leads to unconsciousness or death by asphyxiation. 

Asphyxiants can be classified into:

Asphyxiant Description Examples
Simple Asphyxiants Inert gases that displace oxygen
  • Noble gases
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Hydrocarbons
Chemical Asphyxiants Reduce the body's ability to absorb, transport or utilize oxygen
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide
  • Hydrogen sulphide
Irritant Asphyxiants Damage the respiratory tract
  • Ammonia
  • Formaldehyde
  • Methyl isocyanate
Systemic Asphyxiants Produce significant sytemic toxicity by specialized mechanisms
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide

questions.text:
You are posted in the pediatric hematology department as a first-year postgraduate. All of the following cases you encounter are at an increased risk of developing leukemias except:

Case 1: A 2-year-old child with neurofibromatosis type 1

Case 2: A 4-year-old with Fanconi syndrome

Case 3: A 1-year-old with ataxia-telangiectasia

Case 4: A 3-year-old with severe combined immunodeficiency

Case 5: A 10-month old with pernicious anemia
questions.solution:
Fanconi’s anemia (not syndrome) predisposes to the development of childhood leukemias eg: B-ALL due to defective DNA repair. Fanconi syndrome is a syndrome of inadequate reabsorption in the proximal renal tubules. Congenital pernicious anemia does not predispose to leukemias.

Factors predisposing to childhood leukemias

  • Genetic conditions:
    • Fanconi’s anemia
    • Bloom syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • Down syndrome
    • Severe combined immunodeficiency
    • Neurofibromatosis 1   
    • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
    • Diamond-Blackfan anemia
    • Schwachman diamond syndrome
    • Kostmann syndrome
  • Environmental factors:
    • Ionizing radiation
    • Alkylating agents
    • Nitrosoureas
    • Epipodophyllotoxin
    • Benzene exposure
    • Advanced maternal age.

Chronic lymphoid leukemia is associated with warm and cold types of autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: What does the Hounsfield unit depend on?
questions.solution:
Hounsfield unit (HU) depends on the linear attenuation co-efficient.

Attenuation is the reduction of the intensity of an X-ray beam as it traverses matter. HU is used to measure the X-ray attenuation values in CT scanning, thus quantifying the radiodensity of the tissue. 

Tissues Hounsfield unit
Cortical bone

+1000 HU (Bright white)
Solid soft tissue

+40 to +80 HU (sometimes upto +300) 
Acute hemorrhage +45 to +65 HU 
Water 0 HU (Grey) 
Fat -100 HU 
Lungs -950 to -700 HU
Air -1000 HU (Jet black)

The Hounsfield scale, named after Sir Godfrey Hounsfield invented CT in the year 1972 and was awarded Nobel Prize for Medicine in the year 1979.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presented with frequent falls and tingling in his extremities. On examination, an unsteady gait with a positive Romberg sign was noted. Additionally, there was loss of proprioception and vibration sense and deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Blood investigations revealed the following. Deficiency of which of the following vitamins is the likely cause of this condition?

Hemoglobin: 8 mg/dl

Peripheral smear: Macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with involvement of the dorsal column and investigations showing macrocytic anemia is suggestive of subacute combined degeneration (SACD) of the spinal cord. It is due to a deficiency of vitamin B12 which is involved in myelin synthesis.

The most severely affected regions are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels.

The clinical features include:

  • Peripheral nerve and spinal cord involvement
  • Paresthesias in the hands or feet  
  • Weakness and unsteadiness of gait 
  • Loss of vibration or joint position sense in the legs
  • Mental slowing, depression, confusion, delusions, and hallucinations

MRI spine shows diffuse myelopathy and areas of demyelination. Treatment involves a replacement regimen of vitamin B12 intramuscular daily injections of 1000 μg for the first week followed by weekly 1000 μg injections for 1 month. Monthly injections are given thereafter.

While vitamin E deficiency can also cause SACD, it is rare and is associated with hemolytic anemia.

Related Pearl: Neurological Manifestations in Deficiency Diseases

Neurological
manifestations

Dementia, encephalopathy Vitamin B12, nicotinic acid, thiamine, folate 
Seizures Pyridoxine
Myelopathy Vitamin B12, vitamin E, folate, copper
Myopathy Vitamin D, vitamin E
Peripheral neuropathy Thiamine, vitamin B12, and many others
Optic neuropathy Thiamine, vitamin B12, and many others

questions.text:
Tis classification is used for the staging of:
  1. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  2. Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS)
  3. Paget’s disease
  4. Inflammatory carcinoma
  5. Colloid carcinoma
questions.solution:
Tis classification is used for the staging of ductal carcinoma in situ and Paget’s disease only.

Tis means carcinoma in-situ. 

  • Tis (DCIS) - includes ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  • Tis (Paget) - includes Paget's disease of the nipple NOT associated with evident invasive carcinoma and/or carcinoma in situ (DCIS) in the underlying breast parenchyma

According to the latest American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) classification system (8th edition), lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is not included in Tis since it is a benign entity.

LCIS is considered a proliferative disease that has a risk of developing breast carcinoma in the future, and hence, it is not included in the classification system. Pleomorphic LCIS is also considered a benign condition.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the mediastinum?

choices.text: Heart enclosed in the pericardium occupies the middle mediastinum
Thymus remnants may be present in the middle mediastinum
Posterior boundary of posterior mediastinum corresponds to T1-T4 vertebrae
Lower border of anterior mediastinum extends more inferiorly than posterior mediastinum

questions.solution:
The heart enclosed in the pericardium occupies the middle mediastinum. 

The middle mediastinum is the broadest part of the inferior mediastinum and contains the pericardium, heart, tracheal bifurcation, and corresponding vessels and nerves.

Option B: The thymus or its remnants are present in the superior and anterior mediastinum. 

Option C: The posterior mediastinum is bounded: 

  • Anteriorly by
    • Tracheal bifurcation
    • Pericardium
    • Pulmonary vessels
  • Posteriorly by
    • Bodies of T5-T12 vertebrae 
  • Anteroinferiorly by
    • Arched posterior 1/3rd of the central portion of the diaphragm

Option D: The lower border of the posterior mediastinum extends more inferiorly as compared to the anterior mediastinum. 

Related Pearl: Divisions and contents of the mediastinum

Major contents of thoracic cavity
Superior mediastinum
  • Trachea
  • Esophagus
  • Thoracic duct
  • Thymus
  • Vessels-
    • Aortic arch
    • Left common carotid artery
    • Left subclavian artery
    • Brachiocephalic trunk
    • Right and left brachiocephalic veins
    • Superior vena cava (upper half)
    • Azygos vein near its opening into superior vena cava
  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve
Inferior mediastinum Anterior
  • Thymus (inferior extension)
  • Mediastinal branches of internal thoracic vessels
  • Sternopericardial ligaments
Middle
  • Heart
  • Phrenic nerve
  • Tracheal bifurcation and bronchi
  • Roots of great vessels
    • Ascending aorta
    • Superior vena cava (lower half)
    • Inferior vena cava
    • Pulmonary trunk and branches
    • Pericardiophrenic arteries and veins
Posterior
  • Thoracic aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Esophagus
  • Vagus nerve
  • Azygos vein
  • Hemiazygos vein

questions.text: A patient who has sustained a head injury lost his consciousness immediately, and after a few minutes, the patient became fully alert and attentive. However, the patient had headache, dizziness, faintness, nausea, a single episode of emesis. The severity of head injury is ________
questions.solution:
These clinical features are suggestive of a minor head injury in this patient.

In minor head injury, the patient who has briefly lost consciousness or been stunned usually becomes fully alert and attentive within minutes

Other options:

  1. Head injury of intermediate severity: Patients who are not fully alert or have persistent confusion, behavioral changes, extreme dizziness, or focal neurologic signs such as hemiparesis.
  2. Severe head injury: Patients who are comatose from the moment of injury

questions.text: A patient from a hilly area was referred with a partial small bowel obstruction confirmed on CECT. Conservative management was tried for a week, but he continued to deteriorate and was taken up for emergency laparotomy. On post-operative day 7, he developed atrial fibrillation. Investigations revealed elevated free T3 and free T4 levels. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the Jod-Basedow phenomenon, likely due to the administration of an iodine-containing contrast agent during CECT.

This phenomenon is characterized by hyperthyroidism due to enhanced thyroid hormone production following the administration of contrast agents and other iodine-containing substances. This occurs in:

  • Patients with autonomous thyroid nodules
  • Patients with pre-existing subclinical hypothyroidism (endemic iodine deficiency in hilly areas)

Option B: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is characterized by the transient inhibition of thyroid iodide organification by excess iodine, thereby decreasing thyroid hormone synthesis.

Option C: Basedow disease is another name for Graves' disease.

Option D: Plummer disease is another name for toxic multinodular goitre.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was taken up for a cesarean section. Following the administration of spinal anaesthesia, she suddenly developed hypotension.  Which of the following would be the vasopressor of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is the vasopressor of choice to manage hypotension caused by spinal anaesthesia in pregnancy.

Phenylephrine produces lesser fetal acidosis and has lesser fetal transfer than ephedrine. Ephedrine was recommended in the past; however, its use has declined since it is associated with fetal acidosis and base deficit.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors recognize fungi?
questions.solution:
C-type lectin receptors (CLRs) detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi.

The various classes of innate immune receptors are as follows:

 Receptors Location Function
Toll-like receptors Plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles

Important TLRs and molecules recognised:

  • TLR2 - peptidoglycan of gram + bacteria, lipopolysaccharide of Leptospira
  • TLR3 - dsRNA viruses
  • TLR4Q - Chlamydia and lipopolysaccharide
NOD-like receptors Cytosol of immune cells and epithelial cells
  • Recognise substances from necrotic cells and microbial products
  • Signals via inflammasome which activates caspase and IL-1
C-type lectin receptors  Plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells
  • Detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi
RIG-like receptors Cytosol of most cell types
  • Detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of infected cells
  • Stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines
  • Recognize short bacterial peptides containing N-formyl methionyl residues and stimulate chemotaxis
Mannose receptors Plasma membrane of macrophages, immature dendritic cells, and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells
  • Detect microbial sugars (which often contain terminal mannose residues) and induce phagocytosis of the microbes

Mannose receptor is a soluble pattern-recognition receptor. All the others are surface pattern-recognition receptors.

questions.text: A pathologist observed a metaplastic lesion in a biopsy sample taken from the bladder mucosa of a patient. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Malakoplakia is not a metaplastic lesion of the bladder. It is a type of chronic granulomatous cystitis due to defective phagocytic function that may mimic malignancy.

Metaplastic lesions of the bladder include the following:

  • Nests of urothelium (Brunn nests) may grow downward into the lamina propria resulting in the following lesions -
    • Cystitis glandularis - epithelial cells in the center of the nest undergo metaplasia and take on a cuboidal or columnar appearance
    • Cystitis cystica - epithelial cells retract to produce cystic spaces lined by flattened urothelium
  • Squamous metaplasia - in response to injury, urothelium is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Nephrogenic adenoma - due to implantation of shed renal tubular cells at sites of injured urothelium, resulting in replacement of urothelium by cuboidal epithelium with a papillary growth pattern

questions.text: Split pleura sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
A split pleura sign is seen in empyema. 

Empyema is defined as a collection of pus in the pleural cavity. It is usually associated with pneumonia but may also develop after thoracic surgery or trauma.

A hallmark feature of empyema on CT imaging is the split pleura sign, where the pleura divides into the parietal and visceral layers. This sign is considered the most sensitive and specific indicator of empyema on CT, helping to distinguish it from peripheral lung abscess.

CT scan showing split pleura sign:

questions.text: Identify the false statement among the following regarding Vitamin D.

choices.text: It is a major inducer of Calbindin that helps in the active transport of calcium.
It induces the expression of RANK ligand which promotes osteoclast differentiation
It increases the proliferation of parathyroid gland
It has antiproliferative effect on keratinocytes, breast cancer and prostate cancer

questions.solution:
Vitamin D has an antiproliferative effect on parathyroid cells.

It is an inducer of Calbindin that helps in the active transport of calcium.

Both Viamin D3 and PTH induce the expression of RANK ligand, which promotes osteoclast differentiation and increases osteoclast activity, by binding to RANK on osteoclast progenitors and mature osteoclasts.

It also has antiproliferative effect on keratinocytes, breast cancer and prostate cancer.

questions.text: Which of these terms is used for paired t tests?
questions.solution:
Paired t tests are also called correlated pairs t test, paired samples t test, or dependent samples t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: An adolescent girl with atrophic rhinitis is using kemicetine antiozaena solution. Which of the following is not a component of this solution?
questions.solution:
Sodium bicarbonate is not a component of kemicetine antiozaena solution. It is used in alkaline nasal solution.

The components of kemicetine antiozaena solution are:

  • Chloramphenicol
  • Oestradiol
  • Vitamin D2. 

It is used in the medical management of atrophic rhinitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the areas marked in the given image?

choices.text: A is a type of association fiber
C is content of interpeduncular fossa
D is devoid of blood brain barrier

questions.solution:
A is anterior commissure, which is a type of commissural fiber, not association fiber.

B is lamina terminalis

C is the mamillary body and is a content of interpeduncular fossa.

D is the pineal gland, which does not have blood-brain barrier.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with complaints of chronic diarrhea, loss of weight, and hair loss. On examination, pallor, nail atrophy, and abnormal skin pigmentation were noted. On endoscopic evaluation, multiple sessile polyps were visualized in the small bowel and colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of intestinal polyps, cutaneous pigmentation, and diarrhea points toward a diagnosis of Cronkhite–Canada syndrome.

It is a non-hereditary polyposis syndrome that occurs at a mean age of 50 years.

Clinical features include:

  • Diarrhea and abdominal pain
  • Nail atrophy, hair loss, and cutaneous hyperpigmentation
  • Cachexia and anemia
  • Characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the stomach, small intestine, and colon due to abnormalities in the nonpolypoid mucosa

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: Radiotherapy is indicated when the spread of angiofibroma extends to which site?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is used for intracranial extension of disease when tumour derives its blood supply from the internal carotid system. Recurrent angiofibromas have also been treated by radiotherapy.

Conformal radiotherapy in extensive juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) or intracranial extension provides a good alternative to conventional radiotherapy regarding disease control and radiation morbidity.

questions.text: In a patient who is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, what does declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc indicate?
questions.solution:
In patients who are both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc are indicative of chronic infective hepatitis.

Anti-HBc IgM antibody signifies acute infection/window period, whereas, the presence of IgG anti-HBc indicates chronic infection. However, there is no test available to directly detect the IgG anti-HBC. Over a period of months, the IgM anti-HBc antibodies are replaced by the IgG anti-HBc antibodies. Thus a decline of IgM antibodies in the presence of rising total anti-HBC indicates that the IgM is being converted to IgG and thus the infection is chronic.  

HBeAg, HBV-DNA, and DNA polymerase appear in serum soon after HBsAg, and all signify active viral replication.

Occasionally, mutated strains of HBV emerge that do not produce HBeAg but are replication-competent and express HBcAg.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - +/- +/- IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG -

Post-vaccination

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the pathogenesis period of a disease?

choices.text: Recovery is seen in this period
Entry of causative agent is seen

questions.solution:
Primary prevention is not possible in the pathogenesis period of a disease. It can only be done in the period of pre-pathogenesis.

The two phases in the natural history of a disease include:

  • Period of pre-pathogenesis: It is before the onset of disease in humans. The disease agent has not entered the host, but the factors favouring the disease already exist. Primary prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
  • Period of pathogenesis: It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death or disability. Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period. It isn't always characterised by the presence of disease symptoms as it also includes subclinical cases.

questions.text: A 1.4 Kg neonate is born at 29 weeks of gestation. The sonologist performing a neurosonogram is most likely to find an intracranial hemorrhage in the:
questions.solution:
Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in premature infants occurs in the gelatinous subependymal or germinal matrix.

In preterm infants, the germinal matrix (situated ventrolateral to lateral ventricles) is extensive and highly vascular which makes them prone to bleeding. Germinal matrix normally involutes during the third trimester.

Major neuropathologic lesions associated with very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants are intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and periventricular leukomalacia (PVL).

Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is characterized by focal necrotic lesions in the periventricular white matter.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding gout?

choices.text: More common in males than females
Abrupt fall in uric acid levels can precipitate an attack of gout
Chronic gouty arthritis is the most common clinical manifestation of gout

questions.solution:
Acute gouty arthritis is the most common clinical manifestation of gout, not chronic.

It is more common in men than in women. An abrupt fall in uric acid levels will precipitate an attack, as uric acid itself suppresses inflammatory cytokines.

Inflamed Heberden's or Bouchard's nodes may be the first manifestation of gouty arthritis.

Heberden and Bouchard nodes are also usually seen in osteoarthritis.

questions.text: Extracellular concentration of a positive ion (with valency = 1)  is 100mmol/L and its intracellular concentration is 10mmol/L, the potential across the membrane using Nernst equation is (mV)_______
questions.solution:
The potential of a positive ion across the membrane using Nernst equation is +60mV.

Where, z is valency in the formula.

Deriving the numerical value: 

EMF = 61/1 *log 10/100

         = 61

The choice of concentration of the ion placed in the numerator and denominator does not matter because the formula is only used to derive the numerical value and not the sign ( +/- ). Mathematically, log (100/10) = 1  and log (10/100) = - 1. Hence, changing the numerator and denominator only changes the sign and the numerical value remains the same.

Deciding the sign/charge: A positive ion with greater concentration extracellularly will try to diffuse inside the cell. A positive intracellular potential is required to prevent this. Hence the sign/charge (potential) is positive (+).

Hence, the potential across the membrane using the Nernst equation is +60mV (the closest answer chosen).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man on routine dental checkup was found to have the following finding on orthopantomogram. What is the reason for the finding marked with the arrow?
questions.solution:
The given orthopantomogram shows a right-sided clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion suggestive of a stafne bone cyst. It is the most common type of ectopic salivary tissue.

It presents as an asymptomatic, clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion at the angle of the mandible, characteristically below the inferior dental neurovascular bundle. It is more common in males. Usually, no treatment is required.

A dentigerous cyst is a cyst in relation to an unerupted tooth. Most commonly involves the 3rd molar. It is managed by enucleation and removal of the tooth.

questions.text: According to the expanded New Ballard score, which of the following criteria can be assigned 5 points?
questions.solution:
According to the expanded New Ballard score, 5 points (maximum score) can be assigned to only 2 of the criteria:

  • Popliteal angle (criteria for neuromuscular maturity)
  • Skin (criteria for physical maturity)

Ballard score is used for gestational age assessment.

For all other criteria, 4 is the maximum score.

-1 is the minimum score for all criteria except posture and arm recoil. For both these, 0 is the minimum score. And for plantar surface and eye/ear, -2 is the minimum score.

questions.text: What is the first-line treatment for a patient presenting with the finding shown below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Ivermectin is the first-line drug for the treatment of cutaneous larva migrans.

The first-line drugs used in cutaneous larva migrans include:

  • Ivermectin - 200μg/kg orally single dose
  • Albendazole - 400mg orally for 3 days

questions.text: You are inserting Nova-T in a patient for spacing of births. This device contains______.
questions.solution:
Nova-T contains both copper and silver. The addition of the silver increases its effective lifespan.

In copper-carrying devices, copper wire is wrapped around the vertical stem of a polypropylene frame. Some of them have copper wire wrapped around the arms too. Based on the surface area, they are of various types:

  • Copper T 380 A
  • Multiload copper 250
  • Copper T 200
  • Copper 7
  • Copper T 220
  • Nova-T

They are effective for 3–5 years. It is estimated that about 50 mcg of copper is eluted daily in the uterus. Copper T 380A, known as Paraguard, has a lifespan of 10 years. Nova T has a lifespan of 5 years.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with AIDS presents to the local clinic complaining of fever, nausea, vomiting and confusion. A lumbar puncture is performed and the microscopic appearance of India ink-stained CSF specimen is given below. Which of the following drugs is most beneficial in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the India ink preparation demonstrating clear halos is suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. Flucytosine and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of this condition.

C. neoformans spreads from inhalation of the yeast cells in pigeon feces, causing infection in HIV/AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. It causes influenza-like respiratory infection in immunocompetent persons. In immunocompromised individuals, it disseminates to CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and patients may complain of headaches, neck stiffness, and disorientation, as in this case. Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of yeast cells or cryptococcal antigen in CSF. India ink stain is used to demonstrate capsulated budding yeast cells in CSF as they have a distinctive appearance because their capsules exclude ink particles. Rapid detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF and blood can also be done. Colonies develop within a few days on most media at room temperature or 37°C. Media with cycloheximide should be avoided as it inhibits Cryptococcus.

Combination therapy of amphotericin B and flucytosine has been considered the standard treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

Other options: 

Ketoconazole is usually used for chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Nystatin is also used for mucocutaneous forms of candidiasis.

Miconazole is used for topical fungal infections like oral thrush, and vaginitis.

questions.text: Extracorporeal photopheresis is used in the management of which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Extracorporeal photopheresis is a systemic therapy used for mycosis fungoides. 

The procedure consists of three stages: 

  1. Leukapheresis
  2. Photoactivation (with psoralen and UVA)
  3. Reinfusion of buffy coat

After exposure to UVA, psoralen binds covalently to DNA in separated leukocytes leading to cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. These apoptotic leukocytes when reintroduced into the peripheral circulation are phagocytosed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs). These APCs then produce tumor suppressor cells against the malignant cells responsible for mycosis fungoides.

Skin-directed therapy is preferred in the early stages whereas advanced stages require systemic therapy. 

Skin-directed therapies:

  • Topical corticosteroids
  • Topical chemotherapy: nitrogen mustard (mechlorethamine) and carmustine (BCNU)
  • Topical rexinoids
  • Phototherapy and photochemotherapy (PUVA)
  • Radiotherapy and electron beam therapy: Mycosis fungoides and variants are highly radiosensitive

Systemic therapies:

  • Immunotherapy: Pegylated IFN‐α
  • Oral Retinoids and rexinoids
  • Combination therapy
  • Systemic chemotherapy
  • Extracorporeal photopheresis (ECP)
  • Toxin therapies: Denileukin diftitox
  • Monoclonal antibody therapy
  • Histone deacetylase inhibitors.

questions.text: A victim of child trafficking was brought to you by the police for age determination. Which of the following would you use as an accurate method for determining the same?
questions.solution:
From the given options, mineralization of teeth is the more accurate method of age determination in childhood.

The relationship between the chronological age and dental age is stronger than between chronological age and skeletal age.

Two aspects of tooth development have been used in the estimation of dental age:

  • The emergence of teeth - superior part of the crown of the tooth appearing level with the surface of the alveolar bone
  • The stage of mineralization of crowns and roots during development

Estimation of dental age using mineralization stages of crowns and roots of developing teeth includes visualization from a radiographic image. This helps in viewing both erupted and unerupted teeth. It is a more accurate method of estimating age than emergence, because emergence is an event whose exact time of occurrence is not accurately known.

The study of dental microstructure is the most accurate method of age determination in childhood. This involves counting perikymata (incremental lines on the surface of tooth enamel).

Note: Eruption is a continuous process by which a tooth moves from its crypt in the jaw bone to its position of occlusion in the mouth. It is different from emergence. Emergence denotes that a tooth has pierced the gingiva.

questions.text: A 21-year-old young man presents with a neck mass. Past history is significant for surgical removal of a pheochromocytoma 6 months ago. On examination, a marfanoid habitus is noted along with the following finding. Which of the following should the patient be screened for?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing mucosal neuromas are suggestive of MEN2B syndrome. This condition is associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. 

The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases of multiple endocrine organs. Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors, either synchronously (at the same time) or metachronously (at different times).

MEN2 syndrome occurs due to abnormal activation of the RET gene. Medullary carcinoma is seen in both MEN 2A and 2B syndromes. However, it tends to be more aggressive and metastasizes more frequently in MEN2B syndrome.

Note: RET gene is deactivated in Hirschsprung disease.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Which of the following provisions is included in BNS Section 22/IPC section 84?

choices.text: Child under 7 years is not liable for the act
A person of unsound mind is not liable for the act
A person who has committed an act under involuntary intoxication  is liable
A person who  commits an act under voluntary intoxication is not liable

questions.solution:
BNS Section 22 (previously IPC section 84) states that the act of a person of unsound mind is not liable for punishment/ prosecution. 

The defence under this section requires the following elements to be established:

  1. The accused was suffering from unsoundness of mind at the time of doing the act.
  2. The accused was incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he was doing what was either wrong or contrary to law.

In 1843, the accused Mc Naughten of Scotland killed Mr. Drummond, the private secretary of the British Prime Minister Sir Robert Pel, believing under a mistake that he was killing the Prime Minister. He pleaded insanity and the House of Lords acquitted him of the murder. This generated a lot of public sentiment and debate and the pressure was so much that ultimately the House of Lords had to constitute a special committee of its own judges to finalize the law which came to be known as McNaughten's Rule. 

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

BNS section

Previous IPC Section

Deals with

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs shows concentration-dependent killing?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides exhibit concentration-dependent killing and are preferably dosed once daily for maximum effect.

Peak concentration above MIC (minimum inhibitory concentration) matters for certain classes of drugs for their antimicrobial action. It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. The period during which the concentration remains above MIC is not relevant for such drugs. Aminoglycosides and quinolones have this property.

Time-dependent killing: The antimicrobial action is dependent on the period for which the concentration of drug remains above the MIC. Penicillins, 5-fluorocytosine and vancomycin have this property.

questions.text: Up to which level does the bronchial artery supplies blood to the lungs?
questions.solution:
The bronchial artery supplies the lungs up to the respiratory bronchiole.

Bronchial arteries are derived from the descending thoracic aorta either directly or indirectly. They travel and branch with the bronchi, and terminate around the level of the respiratory bronchioles.

Pulmonary arteries alone perfuse the further distal pathways including the alveolar ducts and the alveoli.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy with CTEV is undergoing corrective treatment. He is scheduled for a posteromedial soft tissue release procedure. You see the anaesthesia resident mark out the points shown in the image on his back. In what anaesthetic procedure are these landmarks used?
questions.solution:
The landmarks depicted in the image are in reference to caudal anaesthesia. It is a common regional technique in paediatrics for procedures below the diaphragm, including urogenital, rectal, inguinal, and lower extremity surgery. 

Caudal anaesthesia involves deposition of local anaesthetic in the caudal epidural space, accessed through the sacral hiatus. Sacral hiatus is formed by the unfused S4 and S5 laminae and is covered by the sacrococcygeal ligament.

The lines joining the posterior superior iliac spines and sacral hiatus make an equilateral triangle. The sacral hiatus is felt as a groove or notch above the coccyx and between two bony prominences, the sacral cornua.

It is better appreciated in children than in adults and hence it is a common regional technique among pediatric patients.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of  T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive).

The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. 

ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.

Clinical features of ALL include: 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

questions.text: A neonate is being examined after delivery. The delivery was complicated by shoulder dystocia which led to the injury of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. Which of the following deformities is least likely to be seen in this neonate?

choices.text: Abduction and medial rotation at shoulder joint
Sensory loss along the outer aspect of the arm

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, upper cervical trunk injury causes Erb's or Erb-Duchene palsy. This palsy involves adduction and medial rotation at the shoulder, and not abduction. 

The most common cause of Erb's palsy is the undue separation of head and neck i.e. fall on shoulder and birth injuries. The stretching causes damage to the upper trunk (C5, C6). Hence, the affected nerves include: 

  • Suprascapular nerve
  • Axillary nerve
  • Musculocutaneous nerve
  • Radial nerve

Erb's palsy has a typical presentation of a policeman's tip or waiter's tip hand deformity. It includes the following features:

  • Arm is adducted and medially rotated at the shoulder joint
  • Elbow joint is extended
  • Radioulnar joint is pronated 
  • Sensory loss along the outer aspect of the arm

The given image below shows classic deformity seen in Erb's palsy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with abnormal movements of the limbs. A lesion of the globus pallidus is suspected. Which of the following did she most likely present with?
questions.solution:
This woman with a lesion at the globus pallidus most likely presented with athetosis: Slow, writhing movements of a hand/arm/the face.

questions.text: Which of the following class of drugs cannot be used in the treatment of patients with bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
The treatment options for asthma do not include IL-1 antagonists (anakinra). Anakinra is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. 

Cytokines mediating airway inflammation in asthma: IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, TGF-β, and chemokines.

Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE. It is available for the treatment of children ≥6 years of age with documented allergen-induced asthma that is inadequately controlled by inhaled corticosteroids.  

The new treatment options for asthma under clinical trial are: 

  • Mepolizumab: anti–IL-5 antibody
  • Benralizumab: anti–IL-5 receptor antibody
  • Dupilumab: anti–IL-4 receptor antibody

questions.text:
Which of the following constitute corpus cancer syndrome?
  1. Obesity
  2. Hypertension
  3. Stroke
  4. Diabetes mellitus 
  5. Endometrial carcinoma
  6. Dysgerminoma
questions.solution:
Corpus cancer syndrome constitutes of:

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Hypertension
  • Cancer of the body of the uterus.

Etiology of endometrial carcinoma: (Mnemonic: Family Has OLD AUNTI)

  • Family history
  • Hypertension
  • Obesity
  • Late menopause/Early menarche
  • Diabetes
  • Atypical endometrial hyperplasia
  • Unopposed estrogen/increased estrogen → Hormone replacement therapy, fibroid, PCOD
  • Nulliparous
  • Tamoxifen therapy (Raloxifene has no genito-urinary action)
  • Infertility/irregular menses.

Protective factors against endometrial carcinoma include the use of OCPs, smoking, and multiparity.

questions.text: You perform a direct laryngoscopy procedure on a patient and notice a pseudosulcus in the larynx. What is this condition due to?
questions.solution:
Laryngopharyngeal reflux is the cause of the pseudosulcus of the larynx. Pseudosulcus of vocal cords is a depression in the vocal cord mucosa due to chronic irritation from the reflux.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was admitted following a crush injury to his left leg. Two days later, his urine/plasma creatinine levels are < 20. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and urine/ plasma creatinine ratio of <20 is suggestive of renal AKI due to rhabdomyolysis-induced acute tubular necrosis.

Rhabdomyolysis is a serious complication of crush injuries. It leads to muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury by the following mechanisms:

  • Direct toxic effect of myoglobin and heme on the PCT
  • Tubular obstruction by precipitation of pigmented casts
  • Renal vasoconstriction can cause FeNa < 1 (unlike other renal causes of AKI)
Indices Prerenal Renal
Spot urine sodium (mEq/L) <20 >40
Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) <1% >2%
Fractional excretion of urea (FEUrea) <35% >35%
Urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) >500 <350
BUN to serum creatinine ratio >20:1 <10:1
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1
Urinary sediment Nil or hyaline casts only Renal tubular epithelial casts, muddy brown granular casts

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman who underwent a renal transplant 4 months ago comes for follow-up. Which of the following would you perform to assess her renal function?
questions.solution:
Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) scan can be used in the evaluation of renal transplant function and may also be used in transplant obstruction. The imaging findings of acute rejection are characterised by diminished flow. 

Tc-99m MAG3 radioisotope is eliminated through the kidney through both glomeruli filtration and tubular excretion and is a measure of both. Indications for 99mTc-MAG3 dynamic renography are as follows:

  • To assess divided renal function and urinary drainage where the collecting system is significantly dilated.
  • To assess differential renal function following surgery or procedure, for example, post-pyeloplasty. 
  • To assess for a urinary leak or possible obstruction following the renal transplant. 

Other options: 

Option A: Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in pediatric imaging for detecting scarring and pyelonephritis. It is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex.

Option B: Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli and has no tubular excretion. Hence, it is used for direct measurement of GFR.

Option D: Captopril DTPA is used for screening in patients with renovascular hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form both the roof, and is a content of the posterior triangle?
questions.solution:
The suprascapular nerve is the content of the lower part of the posterior triangle of the neck. It does not contribute to the roof. 

Lesser occipital nerve, supraclavicular nerve, and great auricular nerve form both, the roof and are contents of the posterior triangle.

Boundaries of the posterior triangle:

  • Anteriorly - the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid
  • Posteriorly - the anterior border of the trapezius
  • Inferiorly - the middle third of the clavicle
  • Roof - superficial fascia containing external jugular vein, posterior jugular vein, the investing layer of deep fascia and cutaneous nerves. The cutaneous nerves include:
    • Great auricular nerve
    • Lesser occipital nerve
    • Supraclavicular nerve
    • Transverse cutaneous nerve
  • Floor - the prevertebral fascia overlying splenius capitis, levator scapulae, and the scalene muscles

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presented with chest pain and fatigue. The chest radiograph is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows calcified pericardium, called an egg-in-cup appearance. It is typically seen in constrictive pericarditis.

In constrictive pericarditis, there is fibrous or calcific constrictive thickening of the anterior and lateral pericardium that prevents normal diastolic filling of the heart. The resulting diastolic dysfunction leads to features of right heart failure. The thickness of the pericardium is best assessed on MRI.

Note: The egg-in-cup (or ball-on-tee) appearance is also a urographic finding seen in renal papillary necrosis.

questions.text: All typical antipsychotics are potent antiemetic except ______
questions.solution: Most first-generation or typical antipsychotics have strong anti-emetic action except for thioridazine. The anti-emetic action is due to blockade of both central and peripheral D2 receptors. Thioridazine has the least D2 blocking activity among typical antipsychotics.

questions.text: Which of the following glycogen storage diseases is also a lysosomal storage disorder?
questions.solution:
Pompe’s disease is the glycogen storage disease (GSD), which is also a lysosomal storage disorder.

A small amount of glycogen is degraded by the lysosomal enzyme, α (1→4)-glucosidase also known as acid maltase. A deficiency of this enzyme causes the accumulation of glycogen in vacuoles in the lysosomes. This is called type II GSD or Pompe’s disease.

Glycogen storage disorders that are associated with the following findings:

  • Liver cirrhosis: Types III, IV, IX GSD
  • Renal dysfunction: Type I GSD
  • Neurologic involvement: Type II GSD

Note: Another GSD that is also a lysosomal storage disorder is Danon disease (or glycogen storage disease Type IIb)

questions.text: You will feel the first urge to defecate when rectal pressure is increased to:
questions.solution:
The first urge to defecate occurs when rectal pressure is increased to 18 mm Hg.

When this pressure reaches 55 mm Hg, the external and the internal sphinc­ter relax, and there is reflex expulsion of the contents of the rectum.

Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon stimulates stretch receptors in the rectal wall. Then, the defecation reflexes travel from the colon and rectum to the spinal cord and back again to produce the powerful colonic, rectal, and abdominal contractions required for defecation.

questions.text: A young woman presents with sudden onset, rapidly progressing ocular pain, photophobia, and blurred vision in her right eye for 1 day.  A deep, 4 mm diameter corneal ulcer, surrounded by stromal infiltrates was visualized. The anterior chamber has small amounts of mucopurulent discharge. She mentions using a cosmetic contact lens which she forgot to remove before sleeping 2 days ago. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The sudden onset and rapid progression of ocular symptoms and ulceration in this patient along with the history of improper contact lens usage are suggestive of a Pseudomonas infection. 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common gram-negative organism isolated from corneal ulcers and is a frequent cause of contact lens–associated keratitis. Other risk factors include chlorinated swimming pools, hot tubs, ventilators, nebulizer, and vaporizer solutions, and ophthalmic solution bottles.

Pseudomonas keratitis has a rapid and fulminant course if left untreated and are associated with a worse visual prognosis than that caused by most other common bacterial pathogens. Pseudomonas spp. can cause corneal perforation in just 48 hours. Treatment is mainly by topical NSAIDs and topical antipseudomonal antibiotic eye drops such as tobramycin 1.3% and fluoroquinolone eye drops. 

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: The posterior chamber in the eyeball is filled with _______.
questions.solution:
The posterior chamber of the eyeball is filled with aqueous humor.

The eyeball is divided into anterior and posterior segments. The anterior segment includes the lens and the structures anterior to it, such as the cornea, iris and two aqueous humor-filled spaces:

  • Anterior chamber:  Located between cornea and iris, contains aqueous humor and communicates with the posterior chamber through the pupil. 
  • Posterior chamber: Triangular-shaped space, also contains aqueous humor, bounded anteriorly by the posterior surface of the iris, laterally by the ciliary body, and posteriorly by the lens. 

The posterior segment includes all structures located posterior to the lens, comprising of the vitreous humor, retina, choroid and optic disc.

questions.text: Ablation of somatosensory area 1 leads to______

choices.text: Loss of tactile but not 2 point discrimination
Loss of tactile and  2 point discrimination

questions.solution:
Ablation of somatosensory area 1 leads to Loss of tactile and 2 point discrimination.

Widespread bilateral excision of the somatosensory area I causes loss of the following types of sensory judgment:

  • The person is unable to localize discretely the different sensations in the different parts of the body. However, he or she can localize these sensations crudely, such as to a particular hand. The brain stem, thalamus, or parts of the cerebral cortex can perform some degree of localization.
  • The person is unable to judge critical degrees of pressure/weight/texture.

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength?
questions.solution:
Replacing alanine with tryptophan will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength

The amino acids which absorb 250-290nm (maximum at 280nm) UV light are Tryptophan (Maximum Absorption), Tyrosine, Phenylalanine.

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the red line in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
The red line indicates an enzymatic reaction taking place in the presence of a competitive inhibitor.

The graph represents the enzymatic reaction velocity in relation to substrate concentration. The black line indicates the reaction taking place in the absence of any inhibitor.

In the presence of a competitive inhibitor, as indicated by the red line,

  • Vmax remains unchanged.
  • Km  is increased.

In the presence of a non-competitive inhibitor, as indicated by the blue line,

  • Vmax is decreased
  • Km remains unchanged

Note:

Suicide inhibitors are specialized substrate analogs. They contain a chemical group that can be transformed by the target enzyme. After binding to the active site of the enzyme, catalysis by the enzyme generates a highly reactive group that forms a covalent bond and blocks the function of the enzyme.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: Which of the following forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis?
questions.solution:
Obturator internus with its fascia forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis.

Muscles forming walls of the true pelvis:

  • Anterolateral wall - obturator internus and the fascia over its upper and inner (pelvic) surface.
  • Posterolateral wall - piriformis
  • Floor - levator ani and coccygeus

questions.text: Solid wastes generally should not contain:
questions.solution:
Solid wastes should not contain nightsoil, which is untreated human waste (feces).

Solid wastes generally contain:

  • Garbage (food wastes)
  • Rubbish waste (papers, plastics, etc.)
  • Demolition products (bricks, masonry, etc.)
  • Sewage treatment residue
  • Dead animals and other waste materials

questions.text: Paracolic lymph nodes are situated_______.

choices.text: Along the main branches of the superior mesenteric artery

questions.solution: Paracolic lymph nodes are located along the marginal artery.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the reticulate body of Chlamydia?
questions.solution:
The reticulate body of chlamydia is a growing and replicative form.

Chlamydia is a gram-negative coccobacillus that has the following features-

  • They are obligate intracellular organisms as they lack the enzymes for ATP synthesis, and are hence dependent entirely on the host cell. 
  • They can exist in two states.
    • The extracellular infective form is called the elementary body.
    • The intracellular non-infective form is called the reticulate body. These reticulate bodies are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the "inclusion body" which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells by iodine or Giemsa stain. The cell of the reticulate body is fragile and pliable, leading to pleomorphism.
  • They are small bacteria about 0.2-0.3 microns in size and are hence filtrable through the pore size of standard bacterial filters.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with cardiac dysrhythmia. On probing, he says he consumed the leaves of the plant shown in the image. What is the active principle of this plant?
questions.solution:
The plant in the image is Digitalis purpurea. Its active principle is digitonin.

Digitalis purpurea contains digitoxin, digitalin, digitonin, and digoxin. It can cause cardiac dysrhythmia in acute toxicity. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: Which of the following is not included under MDS/MPN overlap syndromes?

choices.text: MDS/MPN with SF31B mutation and thrombocytosis

questions.solution:
Myelodysplastic syndrome/ myeloproliferative neoplasm (MDS/MPN) overlap syndromes are a group of chronic clonal myeloid malignancies in which there are features of both MDS and MPN at the time of presentation. According to the 5th edition WHO classification (2022), it includes:

  • Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia
  • MDS/MPN with neutrophilia (previously atypical chronic myeloid leukemia)
  • MDS/MPN with SF31B mutation and thrombocytosis
  • MDS/MPN not otherwise specified

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures formed during the development of the definitive notochord, from the earlier stage to the later stage.

1. Notochordal plate
2. Notochordal process
3. Blastopore
4. Notochordal canal
questions.solution:
The correct order is blastopore - notochordal process - notochordal canal - notochordal plate - definitive notochord.

Notochord formation steps:

  • Primitive knot - The cranial end of the primitive streak thickens to form the primitive knot (primitive node or Hensen's node).
  • Primitive pit (Blastopore) - A depression appears in the center of the knot known as the primitive pit (or blastopore).
  • Notochordal process - The cells in the primitive knot multiply and pass cranially in the midline between the ectoderm and endoderm. They reach up to the caudal margin of the prechordal plate. These cells form a solid chord known as the notochordal process or head process.
  • Notochordal canal - The cavity of the blastopore then extends into the notochordal process to form a tube-like structure called the notochordal canal.
  • Notochordal plate - The floor of the notochordal canal gets intercalated (mixed up) with the endoderm and gradually breaks down. This eventually leads to the formation of a flat plate-like structure notochordal plate.
  • Definitive notochord - The cells from the notochordal plate proliferate to form a solid rod-like structure called a definitive notochord.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of patients with rectal prolapse?

choices.text: Surgery is necessary for full-thickness rectal prolapse
Delorme’s operation is done via the perineal approach
Ripstein's procedure is done via abdominal approach
Abdominal rectopexy is often preferred in high risk individuals

questions.solution:
The perineal approach is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate. 

Abdominal approaches (laparoscopic, robotic, or open) are preferred for younger patients, particularly those with constipation or associated pelvic floor disorders.

Perineal procedures:

  • Delorme's mucosectomy- involves mucosal stripping and muscle plication of the rectal prolapse using interrupted sutures. It is performed externally under regional or general anaesthesia.
  • Thiersch's encirclement- a steel wire, or Silastic or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defaecation
  • Altemeier rectosigmoidectomy- involves removal of the prolapsed rectum and associated sigmoid colon, followed by which a coloanal anastomosis is created. It is often complicated by poor bowel control with faecal soiling secondary to the loss of rectal reservoir.

Abdominal procedures:

  1. Suture rectopexy
  2. Mesh rectopexy
  3. Posterior (Well’s and lvalon’s)
  4. Anterior (Ripstein’s)
  5. Lateral (Orr-Loygue)
  6. Ventral
  7. Resection Rectopexy (Frykman–Goldberg)

The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normal anatomical position.

questions.solution:
This is a cellotape slide demonstrating eggs of Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm/threadworm). A strip of cellotape is applied to the peri-anal area just after the patient awakes (before washing) and then applied to a microscope slide.

Eggs of enterobius vermicularis:-

  • Bile non stained
  • Planoconvex eggs containing larva inside
