questions.text: A child of age 5 years presents with developmental delay and multiple seizure types. The seizures could not be controlled with multiple drugs. EEG shows1-2 Hz spike and slow waves and polyspike bursts in sleep. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

It typically starts between the ages of 2 and 10 years of age. Consists of a triad of

    • Developmental delay
    • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
    • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike–and– slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

 

Patients commonly have myoclonic, atonic, and other seizure types that are difficult to control, and most are left with long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

Other options:

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome) typically, it starts in early adolescence (NOT in childhood). The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike–and–slow- wave discharges (NOT 1-2 Hz spike–and– slow waves)

Landau-Kleffner syndrome is a rare condition characterized by loss of language skills attributed to auditory agnosia in a previously normal child (NOT a child with developmental delay)

West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months (NOT in childhood). Typical EEG picture called hypsarrhythmia (NOT 1-2 Hz spike–and– slow waves, polyspike bursts)

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman who was on HRT for the past 2 years, presented with a 4 x 3cm lump over the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. On examination, a peau d’orange appearance was seen and a hard and fixed lump was palpated over the breast.  Which of the following is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The history and physical examination point towards a diagnosis of breast malignancy. The investigation of choice for confirmation of breast carcinoma is trucut biopsy/core-needle biopsy. An excisional biopsy can be done, in case it is inconclusive.

Trucut needle biopsy permits the analysis of breast tissue architecture. A 14 G- 16 G needle is used. The advantages include a low complication rate, minimal scarring, and a lower cost as compared to excisional breast biopsy. 

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a cytological investigation and, hence, not the investigation of choice. A 22-30 G needle is used for FNAC.

Trucut biopsy is preferred over FNAC as it:

  • Allows a definitive preoperative diagnosis
  • Differentiates between DCIS and invasive disease
  • Allows the tumor to be stained for receptor status, which is important for starting neoadjuvant therapy. 

Image-guided biopsy is used only in the case of non-palpable lesions.

questions.text:
Technetium 99m labeled RBC scan is useful in which of the following patients?
  1. A 56-year-old man with congestive cardiac failure
  2. An 18-year-old boy with inflammatory bowel disease
  3. A 60-year-old woman with a positive fecal occult blood test
  4. A 20-year-old man who developed splenosis following trauma
  5. A 66-year-old woman with a solitary pulmonary nodule
questions.solution:
Tc-99m labeled RBC scan would be useful in patients 1, 3, and 4. The uses of Tc-99m labeled RBC scan include assessment of the following:

  • Assessment of cardiac function in congestive cardiac failure and congenital heart disease
  • Occult gastrointestinal (GI) bleed
  • Vascular lesions like hepatic haemangioma
  • Ectopic splenic tissue (splenosis)

Other options:

Tc-99m labeled leucocytes are used in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). 

18-Fluorodeoxyglucose PET scan is used in tumors, including solitary pulmonary nodules.

questions.text: 1 mCi of any radioisotope equals:
questions.solution:
One millicurie equals 37 megabecquerel.

1 curie = 3.7 × 1010 disintegration/s

1 millicurie = 1 curie / 103 = 3.7 x 107 disintegrations/s = 37 x 106 disintegrations/s

1 Megabecquerel [Mbq] = 106 Disintegrations per second

Hence, 1 millicurie = 37 megabecquerels.

Related Pearl: Important SI units for radiation

Quantity measured Old unit New Unit Conversion Description
Radioactivity Curie Becquerel 1 curie = 3.7 x 1010 becquerel  
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg 1 roentgen = 2.58 × 10-4 C/Kg Amount of radiation absorbed in air.  
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy) 100 rad = 1 gray (or, 1 rad = 0.01 gray)  Amount of radioactive energy absorbed per unit gram of tissue or material.
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv) 100 rem = 1 sievert  Indicates potential danger to health.

questions.text: A 72-year-old gentleman with normal renal functions presents with new onset focal seizures. Which of the following is the most appropriate to manage the patient?
questions.solution:
Levetiracetam is the most appropriate drug to manage the above patient as it has rapid therapeutic effects and no known drug interactions making it especially suitable in this case, considering common presence of polypharmacy in elderly patients.

The other drugs effective for initial treatment of focal seizures include carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, lamotrigine and phenytoin. However, in the given scenario involving an elderly patient, these drugs would not be more appropriate than Levitiracetam because :

  • Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause leukopenia, aplastic anemia, or hepato-toxicity and hyponatremia in the elderly
  • Phenytoin has a narrow therpeutic index and can cause many adverse effects including effects on bone metabolism. 
  • Lamotrigine requires slow titration (to reduce the risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome) and would not be an appropriate first choice when a rapid onset of action is needed as in this case.
All the above drugs are indicated even in focal seizures that evolve into generalized seizures. Valproate can be an effective alternative (second-line agent) in such patients.

questions.text: A teenage girl who recently got diagnosed with PCOS presented with skin lesions on her forehead as shown in the image below. On examination, hirsutism was also noted. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe to this patient?
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are acne. The drugs used to treat acne and hirsutism in a patient with PCOS are OCPs with cyproterone acetate.

The first step in the management of PCOS is weight reduction. OCPs are the drugs of choice for regularisation of cycles. They are also the drugs of choice for hirsutism and acne. OCPs used for PCOS should contain a 3rd/4th generation progestagen like cyproterone acetate. OCPs induce regular menstrual cycles, lower androgen levels and causes thinning of the endometrium.

Insulin sensitizers like metformin have been found to improve metabolic and gynecologic issues. It acts by reducing the insulin level and reducing hepatic production of glucose (liver neoglycolysis). Other benefits of metformin include improvement in fertility rate and reduction of the total and free testosterone levels. It also increases levels of sex hormone-binding globulin. Metformin is contraindicated in hepatic and renal disease.

Treatment of infertility associated with PCOS is done using ovulation-inducing drugs like letrozole and clomiphene citrate. If medical management fails, surgical options like laparoscopic ovarian drilling can be considered.

Note: 

FOGSI, in 2024, has replaced Letrozole as the first-line drug for induction of ovulation in patients with PCOS. However, the FDA approval for the same is still pending.

 

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with poikiloderma?
questions.solution:
Loss of temperature sensation is not associated with poikiloderma.

Poikiloderma is a special skin lesion with a triad of features:

  1. Cutaneous pigmentation (both hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation)
  2. Skin atrophy
  3. Telangiectasia

It may be congenital or acquired. It is associated with mycosis fungoides, dermatomyositis, xeroderma pigmentosum, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is a nodal centre in case of disaster management?
questions.solution:
The district disaster management authority is the nodal center for disaster management. 

It is chaired by either, the District Collector, District Magistrate or the Deputy Commissioner. The Chief Medical Officer of the district is a part of this authority.

questions.text: The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes all of the following symptoms except:
questions.solution:
The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes the following symptoms:

  • Headache
  • Profuse sweating
  • Palpitation (due to tachycardia)

Hypertension is the most predominant sign of pheochromocytoma. Though intermittent hypertension is a classical feature, sustained hypertension is also common.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause interstitial keratitis?
questions.solution:
Diphtheria is not a cause of interstitial keratitis.

Interstitial keratitis is a non-ulcerating, inflammatory reaction of the corneal stroma that is characterized by non-suppurative infiltration and often stromal vascularization. The epithelium and endothelium are not affected. Scarring due to stromal inflammation and vascularization, in interstitial keratitis, can result in decreased vision.

Interstitial keratitis (IK) is a common endpoint of any keratitis that predominantly involves the corneal stroma. So there is a wide range of potential etiologies.

Immune-mediated etiologies Infectious etiologies
    • Cogan syndrome:
    • Interstitial keratitis + deafness + vertigo
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Mycosis fungoides

Bacterial causes:

  • Syphilis; Lyme disease
  • Tuberculosis; Leprosy
  • Brucellosis; Leptospirosis.

Viral causes:

  • Herpes simplex (HSV), Herpes zoster (VZV)
  • Epstein-Barr (EBV), mumps, rubella (measles)
  • influenza, and vaccinia

Parasitic causes:

  • leishmaniasis
  • onchocerciasis
  • trypanosomiasis 
  • plasmodium
  • acanthamoeba

Treatment for IK typically involves the use of topical corticosteroids, as well as appropriate systemic medications for the associated systemic disease.

questions.text: A plain radiograph of a patient shows a destructive lytic tumor that extends into the surrounding soft tissues with a characteristic onion-skin appearance. A biopsy image is shown below. Which of the following is not true about the tumor?

choices.text: It is the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children
It arises in the epiphysis of long tubular bones
Most of these tumours contain a (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation
The amount of chemotherapy-induced necrosis is an important prognostic finding

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma. It arises in the diaphysis of long bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis. 

Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children. It generally affects patients < 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than girls. Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis.

Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen. Plain radiographs show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extend into the surrounding soft tissues. The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an onion-skin fashion. It arises in the medullary cavity and usually invades the cortex, periosteum, and soft tissue.

On microscopy, sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm are seen, which may appear clear because they are rich in glycogen. The presence of Homer–Wright rosettes indicates a greater degree of neuroectodermal differentiation.

The image given below shows the histopathological findings in Ewing sarcoma.

Most Ewing sarcoma family tumors contain an (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation. Variant translocations fuse the EWS to other members of the ETS transcription factor family. CD99(MIC2), FLI1, and NSE would be positive in ES/PNET.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primitive neuro-ectodermal tumor?
questions.solution:
Ewing's sarcoma family of tumors encompasses Ewing's sarcoma and primitive neuro-ectodermal tumors, which are primary malignant small round cell tumors of bone and soft tissue.

Both Ewing's sarcoma and PNETs have a similar natural phenotype, and because they share an identical chromosomal translocation, they should be viewed as two variants of the same tumor that differ only in the degree of their neural differentiation. Medulloblastoma and Pinealoblastoma are CNS PNETs.

Note: Askin's tumor is also a primitive neuro-ectodermal tumor developing from the soft tissues of the thoraco-pulmonary region.

questions.text: Pigment producing atypical mycobacteria is/are:-
questions.solution:
Pigment producing atypical mycobacteria include:-

  • Photochromogens (bright yellow or orange coloured colonies): M. kansasii, M. marinum, M. simiae
  • Scotochromogens (yellow-orange-red colonies): M. scrofulaceum, M. gordonae, M. szulgai

questions.text: You see a newborn with an enlarged clitoris and partially fused labia. You also note features such as frontal bossing, brachycephaly, midface hypoplasia, slender fingers, medial bowing of ulna, and heart abnormalities. Investigation reveals a deficiency of P450 oxidoreductase. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of P450 oxidoreductase (POR) along with the given findings are suggestive of Antley-Bixler syndrome. 

Features of Antley–Bixler syndrome:

These include deficiencies of 17-hydroxylase and 21-hydroxylase along with other congenital anomalies.

It leads to under virilization of males and virilisation of females via an alternate pathway. Virilization of mother is seen because of decreased placental aromatase activity leading to excess androgens in fetus and mother. 

 Congenital anomalies seen are as follows:

  • Head and face: Craniosynostosis, brachycephaly, frontal bossing, severe midface hypoplasia, with proptosis and choanal atresia.
  • Limbs: Humeroradial synostosis; medial bowing of the ulnas; long, slender fingers, with camptodactyly and anterior bowing of the femurs.
  • Malformations of the heart and kidneys.

questions.text: The Hardy-Weinberg law is applicable in populations with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The Hardy-Weinberg law is applicable for infinitely large, static populations with random mating.

Related Pearl: Hardy-Weinberg Law

  • The Hardy-Weinberg Law is related to population genetics.
  • It is based on the principle founded by G.H. Hardy and Wilhelm Weinberg.
  • The law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele tends to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of other evolutionary influences.
  • It is also called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium or principle.
  • It is only applicable for infinitely large, static populations which randomly mate.
  • This law fails in the following conditions:
    • Small and dynamic populations
    • Non random or assortative mating
    • Mutations
    • Gene outflow and genetic drift
    • Migration

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of the following is not included in this condition?
questions.solution:
Cervicitis is not included in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Pelvic inflammatory disease is a spectrum of infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, typically causing:

  • Endometritis
  • Salpingitis
  • Oophoritis
  • Peritonitis

The minimum criteria for diagnosis of PID are:

Pain in the lower abdomen + any one of the following:

  • Uterine tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness

Cervicitis and vaginitis are lower genital tract infections.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient comes with a history of chronic weight loss, loss of appetite, and diarrhea along with pale bulky stools and is diagnosed with malabsorption syndrome. Steatorrhea is defined in this patient by stool fat exceeding:
questions.solution:
Steatorrhea is a symptom defined by stool fat exceeding 7 g per day.

Steatorrhea is the passage of greasy, foul-smelling, difficult-to-flush stools. It is often associated with weight loss & nutritional deficiencies due to concomitant malabsorption of amino acids & fat-soluble vitamins. It is one of the clinical features of fat malabsorption and is noted in many conditions causing intraluminal maldigestion, mucosal malabsorption, or lymphatic obstruction.

Causes of steatorrhea:

  • Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency: Chronic pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis (CF), pancreatic tumors
  • Bile acid deficiency: Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), ileal resection, Crohn disease, small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)
  • Enteropathy or Malabsorption syndrome: Celiac disease (most common), tropical sprue, giardiasis, Whipple disease, amyloidosis, SIBO, abetalipoproteinemia

Screening of steatorrhea is by the detection of fat by Sudan III staining. Stool fat can be quantified by calculating the coefficient of fat absorption (CFA), which is an essential step in the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following marked distances is described as the caliber of a rifled gun?
questions.solution:
The caliber of a rifled gun is described as the marked distance C in the image. Caliber is measured as the distance between two diametrically opposite lands.

It is the internal dimension of the barrel and is measured in millimeters or inches. 

Note: For a smooth barrel weapon, it is measured as the distance between two diametrically opposite points on the inner circumference.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with cervical lymphadenopathy is suspected to have chronic lymphocytic leukemia. What should be the absolute lymphocyte count/mm3 to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnostic requirement for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is absolute lymphocyte count >5000 per cubic millimetre. 

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytosis:

  • CLL - 5000/mm3
  • SLL - <5000 cells/mm3

Note: CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the western world.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with a significant elevation of angiotensin-converting enzyme levels?
questions.solution:
Diabetes is associated with a mild elevation of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels.

Significant elevation of ACE levels is seen in:

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Silicosis
  • Leprosy
  • Gaucher’s disease
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Disseminated granulomatous infections such as miliary tuberculosis

questions.text: An investigator is conducting a study to assess the effect of a mood stabiliser on patients with bipolar I disorder. What does it mean if the difference is significant in the results?

choices.text: p > 0.05 and it is likely by chance
p > 0.05 and it is unlikely by chance
p < 0.05 and it is unlikely by chance
p < 0.05 and it is likely by chance

questions.solution:
When the difference is significant, it means that the difference is unlikely by chance and p will be ≤ 0.05.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: Amphotericin B is associated with normocytic, hypochromic anemia. The most probable reason for this adverse effect is
questions.solution:
Normocytic hypochromic anemia associated with amphotericin B is most likely due to decreased production of erythropoietin.

The anemia usually responds to administration of recombinant erythropoietin. 

Conventional formulation is more likely to cause anemia over lipid formulations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoing treatment for TB visits your OPD for follow-up. His wife states that recently he is forgetting the names of his colleagues and neighbors, but later recollects them correctly. Which drug is implicated to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is the antitubercular drug that is implicated in the causation of transient memory loss.

Neurological toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuritis, and seizures can occur with isoniazid therapy. It is also associated with abnormalities like:

  • Euphoria
  • Transient memory loss
  • Separation of ideas and reality
  • Loss of self-control
  • Florid psychosis

Pyridoxine therapy can prevent and reverse most of the neurological toxicity and mental abnormalities.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

questions.text: Endemic typhus is transmitted by _______
questions.solution:
Endemic typhus is caused by Flea.

Endemic typhus also termed Murine typhus or flea-borne typhus is caused by rickettsia typhi. It is transmitted by fleas and rats are reservoirs. The incubation period is 1–2 weeks. The Weil Felix reaction is positive in 2nd week. Tetracycline is the drug of choice. Rodent control is most important and is best done by BHC and malathion.

questions.text: In which of the following patients is oxytocin not indicated?

choices.text: A primiparous woman with spontaneous premature labor
A multiparous woman with postpartum haemorrhage
A primiparous woman with uterine inertia
A patient with breast engorgement due to inefficient milk ejection reflex

questions.solution:
Spontaneous premature labor is not an indication for oxytocics. Infact, it is an indication for tocolytics.

Uses of oxytocin are:

  • Induction of labor
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Uterine inertia
  • Breast engorgement due to insufficient milk ejection reflex

questions.text: The most common cause of death in Churg strauss syndrome is____
questions.solution: Myocardial involvement is the most frequent cause of death in Churg strauss syndrome and is responsible for 39% of mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cutaneous presentation of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus presents most commonly as a non‐scarring papulosquamous eruption. It can also present as annular polycyclic lesions.

Sites of lesions:

  • Above the waist
  • Around the neck
  • On the trunk
  • Outer aspects of the arms

The image below shows psoriasiform lesions of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after sustaining injuries in a fight. He was able to talk but was disoriented and confused. He could open his eyes spontaneously and also responded to pain by localizing it. What is his Glasgow coma scale score?
questions.solution:
For the given scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 13.

To arrive at this the following clinical clues have to be considered:

  • Eye response: The patient is able to spontaneously open his eyes = 4.
  • Verbal response: The patient is able to speak but is confused = 4
  • Motor response: The patient is able to localize a painful stimulus = 5

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4

Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score

Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who is 10 weeks pregnant, comes with history of fever and chills. She is diagnosed with falciparum malaria. Which of the following drugs will you choose for her treatment?
questions.solution:
The woman is in the 1st trimester of pregnancy and falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of pregnancy is treated with quinine plus clindamycin.

Worldwide, most species of Falciparum malaria are resistant to chloroquine. In all trimesters, pregnant women diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria caused by chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum infection can be treated with a combination of quinine and clindamycin.

Quinine is considered the drug of choice in the first trimester. In the second and third trimesters artemether-lumefantrine can be used, but not in the first trimester.

Vivax malaria during pregnancy is treated with chloroquine as chloroquine is safe in pregnancy and children.

Clindamycin can be used in children for chloroquine-resistant cases. It is safe to use in children and pregnant women.

Option B: Doxycycline is useful in the treatment of malaria but not used in pregnancy.

Options C and D: Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) is not recommended during the 1st trimester of pregnancy because of a lack of safety data.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a substrate for gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Acetyl CoA is not a substrate for gluconeogenesis. Instead, it enters the Krebs cycle for oxidative phosphorylation.

The following serve as substrates for gluconeogenesis:

  • Glucogenic amino acids, alanine being the major contributor (alanine is the source of pyruvate). Glucogenic amino acids are converted into pyruvate, oxaloacetate, succinyl CoA, and alpha-ketoglutarate to enter gluconeogenesis and the Krebs cycle at various points.
  • Lactate
  • Pyruvate
  • Glycerol
  • Propionate (ruminants)

questions.text: A man presents with dysuria and clear urethral discharge. He is sexually active. Gram stain of a urethral swab shows neutrophils but no organisms. Which of the following is the most appropriate culture medium for the most common organism responsible for the above condition?
questions.solution:
A sexually active man with dysuria, urethral discharge and absence of bacteria on Gram staining suggests a diagnosis of non-gonococcal urethritis. The most common organism causing this is Chlamydia trachomatis and thus, the most appropriate culture medium is McCoy cells (human synovial carcinoma cell line).

C. trachomatis is a small gram-negative bacte­rium and an obligate intracellular parasite. Hence, selective culture media like the McCoy cells culture is used to isolate the organism. C. trachomatis appears as an intracytoplasmic inclusion body. It causes urogenital syndromes in men and women. 

Urethritis in men can be caused by Neiserria gonorrheae, C. trachomatis, Mycoplasma genitalium, Ureaplasma urealyticum, Trichomonas vaginalis, HSV, and rarely adenovirus. Gram stain of urethral discharge from gonococcal urethritis would show the presence of ≥ 2 PMNs/1000x field and Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Chlamydial co-infection is common in gonococcal urethritis. In the absence of bacteria on Gram staining, non-gonococcal urethritis is suspected, of which 30-40% of cases are caused by Chalmydia trachomatis. 

Option B: Thayer–Martin agar is used for isolation of Neisseria spp. 

Option C: Robertson’s cooked meat is used for the culture of anaerobes, especially Clostridia

Option D: Pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) broth is used to culture Mycoplasma spp. and Ureaplasma spp.

Note: In women, abnormal urethral gram stain showing >10 PMNs/1000Å~ field with dysuria but without coliform bacteriuria supports the diagnosis of chlamydial urethritis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient was transfused with 2 units of fresh frozen plasma following a road traffic accident. Within 2 hours of the transfusion, he became breathless and his oxygen saturation dropped to 88%. Chest X-ray showed batwing appearance. This condition occurs due to which of the following?

choices.text: Preformed IgM Ab to ABO Ag

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). The presence of antibodies against the Human Leukocyte antigen (Anti-HLA Ab) in the donor blood is implicated in the development of TRALI.

TRALI is defined as an acute lung injury that is temporally related to blood transfusion and causes non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It occurs within the first six hours following a transfusion. Screening for HLA antibodies has been introduced to prevent TRALI.

TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind to recipient leukocytes. The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. Testing the donor’s plasma for anti-HLA antibodies can support this diagnosis.

The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. The transfusion of plasma from male and nulliparous women donors reduces the risk of TRALI.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the given image?

choices.text: Esophageal balloon should be deflated for about 5 mins every 6 hours
Gastric balloon should be inflated first
Pressure in the oesophageal balloon should not exceed  60 mm Hg.
Endotracheal intubation prior to tube insertion reduces the risk of pulmonary aspiration

questions.solution:
The given image shows Sengstaken-Blakemore tube. Pressure in the oesophageal balloon should not exceed 45 mm Hg.

It is used for balloon tamponade in variceal hemorrhage when medical therapy fails or is not available. Initially, only the gastric balloon should be inflated, with 200– 250 mL of air, as this will usually control bleeding. The oesophageal balloon is used in continued bleeding, it should be deflated for about 5 minutes every 6 hours to avoid oesophageal mucosal damage.

Endotracheal intubation prior to tube insertion reduces the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: What is the most common site of foregut cyst?
questions.solution:
Foregut cysts are most often located in the hilum or middle mediastinum.

They are the congenital cysts that arise from abnormal detachments of primitive foregut. Foregut cysts are classified as bronchogenic, esophageal, or enteric. The most common type of foregut cyst is bronchogenic cyst.

Microscopically, the cyst is lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old woman with a history of moderate aortic stenosis presented with fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats for 2 weeks. Blood tests showed the following. Echocardiography revealed an intracardiac mass on the mitral valve. Blood cultures showed growth of Streptococcus gallolyticus. What additional investigation should be performed?

Hb- 9.9 g/dL

WBC count- 16.0 × 10^9 /L

CRP- 187 mg/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and laboratory investigations are suggestive of infective endocarditis caused due to Streptococcus gallolyticus. In this condition, a colonoscopy should be performed.

Streptococcus gallolyticus originates from the gastrointestinal tract and is associated with polyps and colon cancer. Hence, the presence of this organism in the vegetation of infective endocarditis should warrant a gastrointestinal investigation.

questions.text: In the oncology ward, four patients have been diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma. Which of the following patients would you advise for transoral laser microsurgery as the first choice?

choices.text: A patient with vocal cord palsy, with subglottic extension
A patient with tumor limited to one cord, with normal mobility
A patient with tumor invading the thyroid cartilage
A patient with tumor limited to larynx, with fixed cord

questions.solution:
Among the given options, a patient with tumor limited to one cord, with normal mobility will be advised for transoral laser microsurgery as the first choice. TNM staging in this patient is T1a.

Option A: TNM staging here is T2b and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first choice.

Option C: TNM staging here is T4a and the patient is advised for total laryngectomy as the first choice.

Option D: TNM staging here is T3 and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first choice.

TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002)

Stage Description
T1 Tumour limited to the vocal cord(s) with normal mobility
T1a Tumour limited to one vocal cord
T1b Tumour involves both vocal cords
T2a Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with normal vocal cord mobility
T2b Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with impaired vocal cord mobility
T3 Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or  minor thyroid cartilage erosion
T4a Tumour invades thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissue beyond the larynx
T4b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

Treatment of laryngeal cancers:

T stage Treatment
T1a TLM > RT
T1b (mid-cord lesion) RT/TLM > OPL
T2a RT/TLM > OPL
T2b RT ± CT > TLM
T3 CRT
T4a TL> CRT
T4b Palliative management

TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT: Chemotherapy; CRT: Chemoradiotherapy, TL: Total laryngectomy.

questions.text: Case fatality rate is ______.

choices.text: Killing power of a disease in time
Killing power of a disease with no time interval

questions.solution:
Case fatality rate reflects the killing power of a disease with no specific time interval.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: What is the most common location of aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution: The most common location of aortic aneurysms is the infrarenal aorta.

questions.text: The most common subtype of fibromuscular dysplasia is ______.
questions.solution:
Most common type of fibromuscular dysplasia is medial fibroplasia.

Histological subtypes of fibromuscular dysplasia

  • Intimal fibroplasia (focal)
  • Medial dysplasia (multifocal)
  • Adventitial hyperplasia

Medial dysplasia is of further 3 types

  • Medial fibroplasia
    • Most common type and characterized by alternating areas of thinned media and fibromuscular ridges.
  • Medial hyperplasia 
  • Perimedial dysplasia

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman complains of recurrent episodes of constipation and crampy abdominal pain for the last 4 months. The pain is relieved on defecation. After investigations, a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is considered. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
The drug used in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is lubiprostone.

It is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (in female patients >18 years). It acts by stimulating Cl-channels in the intestine and increasing fluid secretion in the gut. This decreases the transit time.

Eluxadoline is an FDA-approved opioid drug for the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS in adults.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: All are catalase positive except:-
questions.solution:
This demonstrates the presence of catalase, an enzyme that catalyses the release of oxygen from hydrogen peroxide.

Method:-

  • One ml of hydrogen peroxide solution, H2 O2 (10 vol), is poured over a 24 hours nutrient agar slope culture of the test organism and the tube is held in a slanting position
  • Alternatively, a small amount of the culture to be tested is picked from a nutrient agar slope with a clean sterile platinum loop or a clean, thin glass rod and dip it in a drop of 10% hydrogen peroxide on a clean glass slide.

Interpretation:-

  • Positive test: Immediate bubbling, easily observed (O2 formed)
  • A false-positive reaction may be obtained if the culture medium contains catalase (e.g. blood agar), or if an iron wire loop is used.

Negative test: No bubbling (no O2 formed)

Positive and Negative Bacteria:-

Catalase positive: All members of Enterobacteriaceae except Shigella dysentriae type 1; Staphylococcus, Micrococcus, Bacillus

Catalase negative: Shigella dysentriae type 1, Streptococcus, Clostridium.

questions.text: A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs in patients with_____
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea is a cause of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis produced as a result of increased HCO3- loss in feces.

This is because a decrease in HCO3- is replaced by an increase in the concentration of Cl-.  This is a measurable anion and hence the anion gap is normal.

Extra - edge : Siggard-Anderson curve normogram is used to plot the acid-base composition of the blood

questions.text: Identify the structures attached to the areas marked 1, 5, and 6 in the tibial plateau below?

choices.text: Anterior cruciate ligament, posterior cruciate ligament, anterior and posterior horns of medial meniscus
Anterior horn of medial meniscus, posterior horn of medial meniscus, anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments
Anterior cruciate ligament, posterior cruciate ligament, anterior and posterior horns of lateral meniscus
Anterior horn of lateral meniscus, posterior horn of lateral meniscus, anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments

questions.solution:
The structures attached to the areas marked 1, 5, and 6 in the tibial plateau are anterior cruciate ligament, posterior cruciate ligament, anterior and posterior horns of medial meniscus respectively.

  • C: Cruciate ligament (Anterior)
  • L: Lateral meniscus (Anterior horn)
  • L: Lateral meniscus (Posterior horn)

questions.text:
You are conducting an epidemiological study on malaria in a town X. The number of cases reported during the last 10 years is given below. What is the most appropriate measure of central tendency for this data?
Year 

No. of cases
2011 250
2012 320
2013 190
2014 300
2015 5000
2016 100
2017 260
2018 350
2019 320
2020 160
questions.solution:
In this scenario, median is the preferred measure of central tendency as there are outliers.

The value of 5000 is an outlier in the given set, i.e., an observed value which is very distant from other observations in the distribution. This indicates the usage of median as the measure of central tendency as it is not sensitive to extreme values, unlike the mean.

By arranging the data in order: 100, 160, 190, 250, 260, 300, 320, 320, 350, 5000, we get the median as (260 + 300) / 2 = 280.

Options A and B: Mean is the most affected by the presence of outliers. Mode is the least affected by outliers but it is used mainly for measuring the central tendency of nominal data.

Option D: Geometric mean can be used for datasets with extreme values but it is not used when the values can be zero or negative. In the given scenario, the number of malaria cases reported in a town can also have a zero value.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: The Median in Biostatistics

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes fabella?
questions.solution:
Fabella is a sesamoid bone. This term is used to describe a bone embedded within a tendon or a muscle. It is a variant of normal anatomy present in 10% to 30% of individuals. Fabella is found within the tendon of the lateral head of gastrocnemius, where it moves over the lateral femoral condyle.

Important sesamoid bones:

  • Patella - largest sesamoid bone in the tendon of quadriceps femoris.
  • Pisiform - tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris.
  • Fabella - lateral head of the gastrocnemius. 
  • Two sesamoid bones can be found in the first metacarpal within the tendons of flexor pollicis brevis and adductor pollicis.
  • Two sesamoid bones can be found in the first metatarsophalangeal articulation within the double tendon of flexor hallucis brevis.

The X-ray image below depicts the fabella (marked with an arrow).

questions.text: Receptors on cell membrane that activate ion channel after binding with agonists are_____
questions.solution:
Nicotinic cholinergic receptors activate an ion channel after binding with its agonist. These receptors are called ligand-gated channels or ionotropic receptors.

Receptors for neurotransmitters are classified into two broad families based on structure and function. They are:

  • Ligand-gated channels (Ionotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, a membrane channel is opened leading to a brief increase in ionic conductance.
    • Important for fast synaptic transmission.
    • Examples - GABAA, GABAC, Nicotinic cholinergic, Glycine and Serotonin (5HT3 subtype).
  • G-protein coupled receptors (Metabotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, secondary messengers are released that modulate voltage-gated channels on neuronal membranes.
    • Examples - GABAB, Muscarinic cholinergic, Catecholamines, Serotonin (all subtypes except 5HT3) and opioid receptors.

questions.text: Four molecules of myoglobin will bind how many molecules of oxygen?
questions.solution:
4 molecules of myoglobin will bind 4 molecules of oxygen.

  • Myoglobin: This is present in skeletal muscles.
  • 1 molecule of myoglobin binds 1 molecule of O2. Thus, 4 molecules of myoglobin will bind 4 molecules of oxygen
  • The shape of O2-myoglobin dissociation curve is the rectangular hyperbola. It lies to the left of Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve (OHDC)(refer figure).

questions.text: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Macro-orchidism (large testicles) are seen in fragile X syndrome, not micro-orchidism.

Fragile X syndrome is the second most common genetic cause of mental retardation (Down syndrome being the most common). It is caused by a trinucleotide mutation, characterised by multiple tandem repeats of the CGG sequence in the familial mental retardation-1 (FMR1) gene. It is associated with the phenomenon of anticipation, where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family.

The affected males are mentally retarded, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60.

The characteristic phenotypic features include the following:

  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Macro-orchidism
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • High arched palate
  • Mitral valve prolapse

When the cells were cultured in a folate-deficient medium, the cytogenetic alteration was discovered as a break in the staining in the long arm of the X chromosome. Because it appeared that the chromosome was “broken” at this locale, it was named as a fragile site.

The given image shows a child suffering from fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: DOC of chlamydia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Treatment of genital Chlamydias:-

Single dose azithromycin regimen is DOC

Treatment of chlamydia in pregnancy:-

  • Although not approved by the FDA for use in pregnancy, single dose regimen of azithromycin regimen appears to be safe and effective for this purpose.
  • However, amoxicillin (500 mg three times a daily for 7 days) can also be given to pregnant women.
  • The fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given cut section image showing multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, and white-greyish with a whorled appearance is Leiomyoma (Fibroid).

Leiomyoma is the most common benign and the most common pelvic tumor in females and is more common in obese females(hyper-estrogenism). They are mostly asymptomatic and the most common symptom is menorrhagia.

Leiomyomas can also present with bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

The image below different types of uterine fibroids classified according to their locations:

Sub-mucous fibroids are the most symptomatic type and intra-mural fibroids are the most common type of uterine fibroids.

Other options:

Option B: Endometrial cancer presents as a polypoid mass protruding into the uterine cavity or as a diffuse thickening of the endometrium. The cut surface may appear white to yellow and may show areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.

Option C: Endometrial polyps are usually small and may be single or multiple. Grossly, they appear as soft, red to pink, often pedunculated (attached by a stalk) masses protruding into the uterine cavity. It presents with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints as an incidental finding on imaging. Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal endometrium.

Option D: In Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna), the uterus may appear bulky and symmetrically enlarged. On the cut section, the myometrium may appear thickened and may show tiny cystic spaces filled with old blood (chocolate cysts). The preferred treatment is hysterectomy. Localised excision or levonorgestrel IUCD is tried in younger women.

The image below shows both the gross and histologic appearances of adenomyosis:

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

questions.text: You are tasked with giving post-operative care to a patient who just underwent open abdominal surgery. Which of the following is the most effective treatment to prevent the patient from developing deep vein thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Heparin, especially low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is more effective for prophylaxis of DVT in patients who have undergone major surgeries where early ambulation is not possible. 

The choice of prophylaxis depends on the type of surgery, trauma, and duration of postoperative immobilisation. Major trauma, abdominal and orthopaedic surgeries warrant a longer duration of postoperative immobilisation. So, the pharmacological method is preferred in these situations.

Mechanical methods are advised in patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours such as after minor trauma. The simplest method is for the patient to ambulate. The activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis.

Additionally, compression stockings are advised. It can reduce the risk of DVT by exerting graduated pressure on the leg, with the pressure being greatest at the ankle.

Advantages of LMWH over unfractionated heparin: 

  • LMWH has a longer plasma half-life and significantly higher bioavailability.
  • The consistent bioavail­ability and clearance of LMWH do not require monitoring of aPTT or anti-factor Xa activity.
  • Dosing is merely based on the patient’s weight.
  • There is a more predictable anticoagulant response than with unfractionated heparin.

LMWH inhibits factor Xa and not IIa activity, with the ratio of anti-factor Xa to anti-factor IIa activity ranging from 1:1 to 4:1.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

questions.text: A few nights before the respiratory physiology exam, a student was suffering from a recurring nightmare. In this nightmare, a knife-wielding horse was chasing him through the streets and threatening to cut off his brainstem at the mid-pontine level. Assuming the horse was proficient in its threat, and performed a bilateral vagotomy as well, which of the following outcomes would occur?
questions.solution:
Transection of the brain stem at the mid-pontine level with bilateral vagotomy causes apneusis.

At mid pontine level lesion, the apneustic centre is intact while the pneumotaxic centre is separated. Concurrent removal of vagus inputs causes this kind of abnormal pattern of breathing characterized by deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief insufficient release.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child abruptly developed symptoms suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder and Tourette syndrome. PANDAS, a pediatric neuropsychiatric disorder, is suspected. Which of the following organisms is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
PANDAS is associated with Streptococcus pyogenes infection.

PANDAS stands for Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections.

The symptoms usually occur abruptly and can include the following:

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
  • Tic disorder
  • Gilles de la Tourette syndrome (coprolalia and tics)

Additionally, children may become moody or irritable, experience anxiety attacks, and/or show separation anxiety. These symptoms are the result of an autoimmune process that leads to inflammation of the basal ganglia and the resultant disruption of cortical-striatal-thalamic axis functioning.

Features:

  • Prepubertal onset
  • Abrupt and episodic course
  • Neurological symptoms
  • Disorders associated: Tics, OCD
  • Associated with a recent history of sore throat

Note: Non-infectious manifestations of streptococcal infection:

  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • PANDAS
  • Guttate psoriasis

questions.text: What is not true regarding a Bochdalek hernia?

choices.text: Early respiratory distress leading to early diagnosis and treatment is a good prognostic sign
The contents of hernial sac commonly includes retroperitoneal fat, left kidney or spleen
The condition is diagnosed prenatally by ultrasonography.
Pericardial cyst is a differential diagnosis.

questions.solution:
Early respiratory distress, within 6 hours of birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.

Features of a Bochdalek hernia:

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Ultrasonography findings:

  • Polyhydramnios
  • Chest mass
  • Mediastinal shift
  • Gastric bubble or a liver in the thoracic cavity
  • Fetal hydrops

Differential diagnosis:

  • Eventration
  • Cystic lung lesion (pulmonary sequestration or cystic adenomatoid Malformation)
  • Group B streptococcal sepsis: associated with delayed onset of symptoms and a CDH often on the right side.
  • Pneumothorax: always occurs on contralateral to the side of CDH.

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair

The viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures.

In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Conventional mechanical ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are the 3 main strategies to support respiratory failure in the newborn with CDH.

Good relative indicators of stability are as follows:

  • Requirement for conventional ventilation only
  • Low peak inspiratory pressure
  • Fio2 <50

If the defect is too large, a porous polytetrafluoroethylene (Gore-Tex) patch is used.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the final structure to drain lymphatics from the stomach?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the intestinal lymph trunk is the last structure to drain lymphatics from the stomach. 

The intestinal lymph trunk is a major lymphatic channel in the abdomen. It receives lymphatics from the pre-aortic group of lymph nodes such as coeliac nodes, superior mesenteric nodes, and inferior mesenteric nodes. The intestinal lymph trunk finally drains into the cisterna chyli.

The lymphatic drainage of the stomach can be divided into four zones as shown in the image below.

questions.text: What should be the minimum age to diagnose a patient with pedophilic disorder?
questions.solution:
The individual should be at least 16 years of age to diagnose the pedophilic disorder.

DSM-5 and ICD-11 criteria for pedophilic disorder:

  • Recurrent, intense sexually arousing fantasies, or behaviors involving sexual activity with a prepubescent child or children (generally age 13 years or younger)
  • The individual is at least 16 years of age and at least 5 years older than the child or children.
  • Persists over a period of at least 6 months.
  • The individual must have acted on these thoughts, fantasies, or urges or be markedly distressed by them.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: Which of the following is a late visual field defect in open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Bjerrum scotoma (arcuate) is a late and clinically significant visual field defect.  

Progression of visual field changes seen in glaucoma:

Early non-specific changes
  • Isopter contraction
  • Baring of a blind spot: Exclusion of blind spot from the central field
Early significant changes
  • Peripheral nasal step (may be early or late)
  • Paracentral scotoma in Bjerrum's area.
  • Siedel’s  scotoma: Paracentral scotoma joins the blind spot
Late significant changes
  • Arcuate or Bjerrum scotoma
  • Ring or Double arcuate scotoma: When 2 arcuate scotomas join together
  • Roenne’s central nasal step

Advanced glaucomatous field defects
  • Tubular vision
  • No light perception: Complete visual field defect.

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: An Injecting Drug User presents to the ED with the lesion (as shown) on his neck. He also has a fever. What is the important cause of his lesion?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis, in this case, is cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis.

Based on the mode of infection, human Anthrax presents in one of three ways:- Cutaneous, pulmonary, or intestinal. All types leading to fatal septicemia or meningitis.

Cutaneous Anthrax:-

  • Transmission - Cutaneous exposure to spores (enter through abraded skin)
  • Cutaneous anthrax used to be caused by shaving brushes made with animal hair.
  • It begins 2–5 days after infection as a small papule that develops within a few days into a vesicle filled with dark bluish black fluid.
  • Rupture of the vesicle reveals a black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring of reaction around the eschar. This is sometimes referred to as a malignant pustule.
  • The lesion is classically found on the hands, forearms, or head and is painless. The disease used to be common in dock workers carrying loads of hides and skins on their bare backs and hence was known as the ‘hide porter’s disease.’

Pulmonary Anthrax:-

  • Pulmonary anthrax, known as ‘wool-sorter’s disease, because it used to be common in workers in wool factories, due to inhalation of dust from infected wool.
  • It occurs in patients who handle raw wool, hides, or horsehair and acquire the disease by the inhalation of spores.
  • This is a hemorrhagic pneumonia with a high fatality rate. Hemorrhagic meningitis may occur as a complication.

Intestinal Anthrax:-

  • Intestinal anthrax, is rare and occurs mainly in primitive communities who eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.
  • An individual may suffer after a day or so from hemorrhagic diarrhea, and dies rapidly from septicemia.

questions.text: Lesion in the given figure is caused by:
questions.solution:
The lesion shown is Bullous Impetigo

  • Bullous impetigo is mainly an infection of infants and young children, caused by Staph aureus strains that produce exfoliative toxins, such as ETA, ETB, and ETD.
  • These toxins blister the superficial epidermis by hydrolyzing human desmoglein 1, resulting in a subcorneal vesicle – Localized staphylococcal skin syndrome.
  • Lesions develop most commonly on skin of the face, buttocks, trunk, perineum, and extremities

questions.text: DOC for mycoplasma pneumoniae is:-
questions.solution:
Mycoplasma pneumoniae:-

  • Infection with M. pneumoniae typically produces mild upper respiratory tract disease. More severe disease with lower respiratory tract symptoms occurs in less than 10% of patients.
  • Tracheobronchitis can occur. Pneumonia (referred to as primary atypical pneumonia or walking pneumonia) can also develop.
  • Incubation period: 1–3 weeks
  • Secondary complications: otitis media, erythema multiforme (Stevens–Johnson syndrome), hemolytic anemia, myocarditis, pericarditis, and neurologic abnormalities.

Laboratory Diagnosis:-

  • Specimens: M. pneumoniae may be recovered from throat swabs, nasopharyngeal swabs, sputum, throat washings, bronchoalveolar lavage, tracheal aspirate and lung tissue specimens.
  • Culture: Isolation medium containing bovine heart infusion (PPLO broth) with fresh yeast extract and horse serum supplemented with penicillin (to inhibit other bacteria), thallium acetate, glucose and with phenol red as a pH indicator
  • A slight, gradual shift in the pH indicator over an 8–15 day period without gross turbidity suggests a true-positive culture.
  • Colonies on agar media: Colonies of M. pneumoniae are small, betahemolytic and have a homogeneous granular appearance (“mulberry shaped)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman having lower abdominal pain and shock is diagnosed with a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. The gynecologist decides to perform an emergency laparotomy via the incision shown in the image below. Which of these structures is not incised in this approach?
questions.solution:
The image shows a midline incision used for emergency laparotomy. Transversus abdominis muscle is not incised in this approach.

Layers of the abdomen pierced in the midline approach (from superficial to deep):

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia (Campers and Scarpa)
  • Linea alba
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Extraperitoneal fat
  • Parietal peritoneum

There are no muscles pierced in this approach. 

Layers of the abdomen pierced in the flanks (from superficial to deep):

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia (Campers and Scarpa)
  • External oblique
  • Internal oblique
  • Transversus abdominis
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Extraperitoneal fat
  • Parietal peritoneum

These layers are shown in the image below:

Clinical Note: Umbilical and epigastric hernias can happen due to a congenital or acquired defect in the linea alba such as a midline abdominal incision.

questions.text: Which substance lowers the threshold for gas discomfort and pain in patients with irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Lipids lower the thresholds for the sensation of gas discomfort and pain in IBS patients.

Hence, postprandial symptoms in IBS patients may be explained in part by a nutrient-dependent exaggerated sensory component of the gastrocolonic response.

questions.text: Who is the father of stereotactic radiosurgery?
questions.solution:
Lars Leksell is the father of stereotactic radiosurgery. He was the inventor of radiosurgery.

Wilhelm Roentgen is the father of radiography.

Option B: Thomas Starzl is the father of modern transplant surgery and performed the first human liver transplant.

Option C: The first CT machine used for clinical purposes was developed by the late Sir Godfrey Hounsfield.

Option D: Robert Egan improved mammography technology further by using industrial film that required less X-ray energy and produced better quality images.

questions.text: An  infant presented with delayed eruption of her teeth. An image of her teeth are shown below. She also has history of blisters over the face, hands and feet on exposure to sunlight since the first week of birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An infant with delayed eruption and reddish discoloration of teeth, and blisters over sun-exposed areas suggests a diagnosis of congenital erythropoietic porphyria. 

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria, also is known as Gunther's disease, is an autosomal recessive porphyria. There is uroporphyrinogen III synthase deficiency, leading to uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulation in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocyte, plasma urine and feces.

Infants present with port wine urine or pink stained diapers, severe cutaenous hypersensitivity, and reddish-brown teeth known as erythrodontia. When illuminated with UV light, the teeth show reddish fluorescence. It may cause non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth in severe cases. 

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a physiological uncoupler?
questions.solution:
Thermogenin is a physiological uncoupler.

Uncouplers mediate their effects by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane to ions, thereby leading to a collapse in the proton gradient established by allowing the H+ to pass across the membrane without going through the ATP synthase enzyme complex.

Examples:

  • Synthetic: 2, 4 dinitrophenol
  • Natural: Thermogenin which is found naturally in the brown adipose tissue, whose function is heat generation, especially in a newborn, and thyroxine

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: The following is not useful to detect basilar invagination of the odontoid process?
questions.solution:
Kohler's line (ilioischial line) is used to diagnose Protrusio Acetabuli

The following lines are used to identify basilar invagination

  • McRae’s line – between the two ends of foramen magnum
  • Chamberlain line – posterior tip of hard palate and posterior tip of F. magnum
  • Mcgregor line – posterior tip of hard palate posterior most part of occipital prominence

Basilar invagination is indentified if the tip of C2 vertebra (odotonid process) is displaced upwards beyond these lines into the base of the skull, causing narrowing of the foramen magnum.

It can press upon the lower brainstem and become symptomic.

questions.text: Which group does the antianxiety drug buspirone belong to?
questions.solution:
The antianxiety drug buspirone is a partial agonist of 5-HT1A receptors. The most important locations of the 5-HT1A receptor are raphe nuclei of brainstem and hippocampus. 

It mimics the antianxiety properties of benzodiazepines but does not interact with GABAA receptors or display the sedative and anticonvulsant properties of benzodiazepines. Buspirone is primarily used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder.

5-HT1A partial agonists are:

  • Buspirone
  • Gepirone
  • Ipsapirone

questions.text: What is Prosopagnosia?
questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia is difficulty in identifying known faces.

In humans, storage and recognition of faces is more strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals, though the left lobe is also active. Damage to this area can cause prosopagnosia.

Patients with this abnormality can recognize forms and reproduce them. They can recognize people by their voices, and many of them show autonomic responses when they see familiar as opposed to unfamiliar faces. However, they cannot identify the familiar faces they see. The left hemisphere is also involved, but the role of the right hemisphere is primary.

The presence of autonomic response to a familiar face in the absence of recognition has been explained by postulating the existence of a separate dorsal pathway for processing information about faces that leads to recognition at only a subconscious level.

Note:

  • Autotopagnosia - inability to recognize or to orient any part of one's own body
  • Simultagnosia - inability to recognize multiple elements in a visual presentation, one object or some elements of a scene can be appreciated but not the display as a whole
  • Somatagnosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one’s own or another’s body
  • Tactile agnosia (astereognosis) -  inability to recognize objects by touch, in the presence of intact cutaneous and proprioceptive hand sensation; caused by a lesion in the contralateral parietal lobe

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic pancreatitis presents with jaundice, severe itching, and weight loss. A smooth, globular mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. You suspect pancreatic cancer. What will be the imaging modality of choice for the evaluation of the tumor?
questions.solution:
Multidetector computed tomography (CT) is the imaging modality of choice for the evalua­tion of pancreatic tumors. It allows an accurate determination of the level of biliary obstruction, the relationship of the tumor to the blood vessels, and the presence of regional or metastatic disease.

For a detailed assessment of the luminal pancreato-biliary anatomy, MRCP should be considered. 

ERCP is reserved for cases requiring therapeutic or palliative intervention. It helps to perform a biopsy and to relieve obstruction by biliary stenting. The invasiveness of ERCP increases the rate of wound infection. Hence, it is not suitable for patients who will be undergoing surgery.

F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) has the ability to differentiate between benign and malignant pancreas tumors. However, false-positive results are seen in FDG-PET. The benefits of FDG-PET over CT scans are yet to be determined.

A CT-scan of pancreatic cancer:

questions.text: Microorganism is arranged characteristically in grape like clusters in gram stain of sputum. Identify the microorganism in image
questions.solution:
Staphylococci are spherical cocci, arranged characteristically in grape like cluster. Cluster formation is due to cell division occurring in three planes, with daughter cells tending to remain in close proximity.

  • GPC (Gram positive cocci) in cluster- Staphylococcus
  • GPC in tetrad- Micrococcus (as cell division takes place in multiple planes)
  • GPC in chain- Strepococcus
  • GPC in pair- Pneumococci, Enterococci (as cell division takes place in single plane)
