questions.text: A young woman delivered her baby on the way to the hospital. While examining her, you notice a perineal tear. This injury could have been prevented by all except:

choices.text: Slow delivery of the head in between contractions

questions.solution:
Perineal injury cannot be prevented in normal labor by routine timely episiotomy. Routine episiotomy is associated with an increased incidence of disruption of anal sphincters and rectal tears.

Indications of episiotomy:

  • Shoulder dystocia
  • Breech delivery
  • Fetal macrosomia
  • Operative vaginal deliveries
  • Persistent occiput posterior positions

Methods of prevention of perineal laceration:

  • Avoid delivery by early extension
  • Deliver head in between contractions
  • Perform timely episiotomy when indicated (not routine).

questions.text: When should folic acid supplementation start in order to be effective in preventing neural tube defects?

choices.text: As soon as pregnancy is diagnosed
At least one month before conception

questions.solution:
• To be effective, folic acid supplementation should be started at least 1 month before conception, and continued through the first 2-3 months of pregnancy.
  • All women desirous of becoming pregnant should consume 400-800 μg folic acid daily; the dose is 4 mg/ day in those having delivered a child with neural tube defect.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic man on treatment presents with complaints of difficulty reading. Fundoscopy shows the following findings. Which antidiabetic drug class is likely to cause this?
questions.solution: The image shows diabetic macular edema, with hard exudates surrounding the blood vessels. It is a rare adverse effect seen with thiazolidinediones, and it resolves when the drug is discontinued.

questions.text: The best diagnostic procedure of M. tuberculosis is:-
questions.solution:
The best diagnostic procedure of M. tuberculosis is sputum examination.

  • Sputum microscopy is the most dependable and conventional method for demonstration of AFB by ZN staining method.
  • The smears are made from thick purulent part of the sputum and then are air dried, fixed by heating, and finally stained by ZN technique.
  • The stained smear is examined under oil immersion lens (100). Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.
  • At least 50,000 to 1 lakh bacilli should be present per milliliter of sputum in order to be examined, taking about 10 minutes before giving a negative report.
  • The presence of at least two or more typical bacilli in the smear is reported as positive for AFB.

The smears are graded depending on the number of tubercle bacilli present in a stained smear on examination by oil immersion lens.

 

Grading of ZN- stained smears for AFB:-

Examination by oil immersion field Number of AFB Interpretation
1 Field 10 or more 4+
1 Field 1-9 3+
10 Fields 1-9 2+
100 Fields 1-9 1+
300 Fields 1-2 Doubtful; repeat smear
300 Fields 0 AFB not seen

questions.text: Gelastic seizures are associated with
questions.solution:
Gelastic seizures are characteristically associated with hypothalamic hamartoma.

Gelastic seizures :

  • Epileptic events characterised by bouts of laughter.
  • Autonomic features are present.
  • Hypothalamic hamartomas present with triad of :
    • Gelastic epilepsy
    • Precocious puberty
    • Developmental delay

questions.text:
Have a look at these pictures from two different patients with the same clinical condition, and answer the questions below:
What is the likely clinical disease in these two patients?
questions.solution:
Hand, foot and mouth disease is a clinical syndrome caused by enteroviruses. The most common enteroviruses causing this syndrome worldwide are Enterovirus 71 (EV71), Coxsackie A6 (CA6), Coxsackie A16 (CA16), and Coxsackie A10 (CA10)

Classically the lesions are papulo-vesicular, but sometimes vesicles are not present.When the lesions only appear on the oro-pharynx, it is sometimes called “herpangina”.

Most cases of Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease are mild and self-limiting. However serious complications (and fatalities) can occur with clinical syndromes such as aseptic meningitis, encephalitis & acute flaccid paralysis. There may also be pulmonary oedema, possibly neurogenic in nature. These complications occur most commonly with EV71.

questions.text: The microscopic appearance of the cervical mucus of a woman having irregular periods and infertility is shown in the image below. In which phase of the menstrual cycle was this sample likely taken?
questions.solution:
The image shows the characteristic ferning pattern of cervical mucus which is seen in the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle.

A specimen of cervical mucus is obtained using a platinum loop or pipette. This is spread on a clean glass slide and allowed to dry. When viewed under the low-power microscope, a palm leaf or fern type pattern is seen in the follicular phase. The ferning is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus secreted under the effect of estrogen.

This pattern disappears after ovulation. If it was previously present, its disappearance is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity. Under the influence of progesterone, the cervical mucus becomes thick and tenacious and impenetrable to sperms and bacteria.

The below image shows the microscopic appearance of dried cervical mucus showing the fern appearance.

questions.text: You select 3  people from a population where the prevalence of anemia is 20% .What is the probability that all the three randomly selected people from the population would have anemia?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the probability of all 3 randomly selected individuals having anemia is 0.008.

In this scenario, the prevalence of anemia is 20%.

So, the probability of a person having anemia in the given population (p) = 20/100 = 0.2.

If selecting 3 people from the population randomly, the chance of the first person having anemia is independent of the second or third person also having it and vice versa. This satisfies the condition for the multiplication rule of probability which states that the probability of two or more statistically independent events all occurring together is equal to the product of their individual probabilities. 

Thus, here the probability that all the 3 randomly selected people from the population would have anemia = 0.2 x 0.2 x 0.2 = 0.008.

 

Related Pearl: Probability

  • Expressed as a decimal fraction never as a percentage. Denoted by p
  • Must lie between 0 (zero probability) and 1 (absolute certainty).
  • Probability of an event cannot be negative.
  • The probability of an event not occurring (q) is q= 1-p

Rule

Description

Example

The Addition Rule

(p) of any one of several particular events occurring = the sum of their individual probabilities, provided the events cannot both happen and are mutually exclusive.

Probability of picking a heart card from a deck is 0.25 and that of picking a club is 0.25. Thus the p (hearts or clubs) is 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.50.

The Multiplication Rule

(p) of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is = product of their individual probabilities.

If the lifetime probability of a person developing a lung neoplasm is 0.25 and the life time probability of developing dementia is 0.01, then the p (lung neoplasm and dementia) is 0.25 x 0.01 = 0.0025.

The Binomial Distribution

 

(p) of the occurrence of a specific combination of mutually exclusive independent events.

The events for which binomial distribution is used have only two outcomes like yes or no, tall or short, male or female, etc.

 

Widely used in genetic counseling.

questions.text: False statement about febrile convulsions is:

choices.text: Absence of a history of prior afebrile seizures
Associated with temperature of 38°C or higher
Antipyretics reduce the risk of recurrent febrile convulsions

questions.solution:
Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizure because the seizure often occurs as the temperature is rising or falling abruptly.

Febrile seizures are seizures:

  • That occur between the age of 6months and 5years
  • With a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • That are not the result of central nervous system infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • That which occur in the absence of a history of prior afebrile seizures
    • Tthere is no post ictal neurological deficit
  • Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizure because the seizure often occurs as the temperature is rising or falling.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought for evaluation of fatigue. On examination, he is jaundiced and mild splenomegaly is noted. He was adopted and his family history is unknown. Peripheral smear findings are shown below. What is the most specific investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows hyperchromic RBCs with loss of central pallor or spherocytes. These findings are suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. The eosin-5-maleimide test is the most specific investigation for this condition. 

It is a flow cytometric test based on the interaction between the dye eosin-5-maleimide and band 3 protein.

Other investigations that can be performed in this condition are:

Acidified glycerol lysis test: Spherocytes from patients with hereditary spherocytosis lyse more quickly than normal red blood cells when incubated in a phosphate buffered hypotonic solution with added glycerol. It has greater sensitivity and specificity than the osmotic fragility test.

Osmotic fragility test: Detects hemolysis by measuring the fraction of total hemoglobin released from red cells when suspended in progressively more dilute salt concentrations.

Note: NESTROFT (Naked eye single tube red-cell osmotic fragility test) is a highly sensitive test used as a screening test for thalassemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in patients with Zieve's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Zieve's syndrome is not associated with thrombocytosis.

Zieve's syndrome is a rare syndrome occurring due to severe alcoholic hepatitis characterized by a triad of:

  • Cholestatic jaundice
  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Transient hyperlipidemia

It resolves with abstinence from alcohol.

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a schizophrenic patient with catatonia?
questions.solution:
Cataplexy is not a feature of catatonia. It is seen in narcolepsy. It involves the sudden loss of muscle tone, with full or partial consciousness.

Psychomotor disturbance is an essential feature of catatonia. Some of the peculiar features of catatonia are given below:

  1. Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  2. Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  3. Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  4. Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  5. Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  6. Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  7. Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  8. Automatic obedience- commands are followed automatically, irrespective of their nature.
  9. Grimacing
  10. Ambitendency- due to ambivalence, opposing actions are carried out.
  11. Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  12. Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.
  13. Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.
  14. Verbigeration- incomprehensible speech.

Catatonia is a feature of, but not exclusive to, schizophrenia. It is more common in psychotic mood disorders and in patients with brain injury and encephalopathies.

questions.text: A 4-year-old orphan child does not seem to seek comfort during times of distress. Even when comforted, the child doesn't seem to be interested in it. This behaviour has been present for more than a year noticed by caregivers when he was shifted between multiple foster homes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests reactive attachment disorder.

Reactive attachment disorder is characterized by the following: 

  • A pattern of inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior toward adult caregivers manifested as:
    • The child rarely or minimally seeks comfort when distressed.
    • The child rarely or minimally responds to comfort when distressed.
  • A persistent social and emotional disturbance involving any two of the following:
    • Minimal social and emotional responsiveness to others.
    • Limited positive affect.
    • Episodes of unexplained irritability, sadness, or fearfulness are evident even during nonthreatening interactions with adult caregivers.
  • The child has experienced a pattern of extremes of insufficient care (evident by early separation, frequent change in caregivers, institutionalization or neglect)
  • The disturbance is evident before 5 years of age and the developmental age of the child is at least 9 months. 

Option A - Disinhibited social engagement disorder is a condition where the child approaches and interacts with unfamiliar adults in either overly familiar behavior, has diminished checking back with caregiver after venturing away (even in unfamiliar settings), with the willingness to go off with an unfamiliar adult.

Option B - Autism spectrum disorder is characterized by deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts as manifested by deficits in socio-emotional reciprocity, difficulty in developing, maintaining and understanding relationships, and deficits in non verbal communicative behaviors.

Option D - Children with intellectual disabilities have deficits in adaptive functioning which, without support, limit functioning in activities of daily life (communication, social participation, independent living) across multiple environments. They are also characterized by having deficits in intellectual functions (reasoning, problem solving, planning, abstract thinking, judgment etc.)

questions.text: A patient was undergoing a surgical procedure under spinal anaesthesia. 30 mins into the procedure, his EtCO2 fell and the patient became apneic. Bag and mask ventilation was given and the patient regained consciousness and began to spontaneously respire in 10 mins. What is the most common cause of the apnea seen in this patient?

choices.text: Systemic toxicity of the local anesthetic

questions.solution:
The most common cause of apnea following neuraxial blockade is hypotension leading to hypoperfusion of the brain stem respiratory centers.

Diaphragmatic paralysis would require the height of the block up to the cervical level (phrenic nerve), which is very rare. However, it can occur in the setting of high spinal up to the cervical level and total spinal anesthesia.

Blockade of the intercostal and abdominal muscles during neuraxial anesthesia is adequately compensated by an unaltered function of the diaphragm and other accessory respiratory muscles.

Systemic toxicity of the local anesthetic would mainly affect the central nervous system and cardiovascular system.

questions.text: Polyuria characterized by low fixed specific gravity of urine is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Fixed specific gravity, in which values remain 1.010 regardless of fluid intake, occurs in chronic glomerulonephritis with severe renal damage.

In chronic kidney disease, as renal function deteriorates, polyuria can be seen due to the impairment of the kidney's ability to concentrate urine.

In diabetes insipidus, although specific gravity is low it is not fixed.

Potomania (beer potomania/beer drinker's potomania/ beer drinker's hyponatremia) is a specific hypo-osmolality syndrome related to massive consumption of beer.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents to the OPD with fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, and productive cough. On examination, there is bronchial breathing on the right side and a dull note on percussion. A chest x-ray is done. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray are suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae. 

Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement. The patients present with red-currant jelly sputum.

Chest X-ray shows:

  • Cavitation
  • Pneumatocele (also seen in S. aureus)
  • Bulging fissure sign: Classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar consolidation causing fissural bulging; or displacement of copious amounts of inflammatory exudates within the affected parenchyma. It is seen in any space-occupying process in the lung such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and lung tumors.

questions.text: You are evaluating an elderly man who is suspected to have hypoactive delirium. Which of the following etiologies is most commonly associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Hypoactive delirium is commonly associated with hepatic and renal encephalopathies.

The hypoactive clinical subtype of delirium can often be confused with depression due to overlapping symptoms of psychomotor retardation and affect.

In delirium, however, the onset of such symptoms is more acute and is usually associated with some medical illness.

questions.text: The most common site of rhabdomyosarcoma in children is _______.
questions.solution:
The most common site of rhabdomyosarcoma in children is the head and neck.

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma and accounts for approximately 3.5% of childhood cancers.

These tumours may occur at virtually any anatomic site but are usually found in the head and neck (25%), genitourinary tract (24%), extremities (19%) and orbit (9%). Retroperitoneum and other sites account for the remainder of primary sites.

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the most common soft tissue tumors among children younger than 15 years and can occur at any site comprised of striated muscle.

Rhabdomyosarcoma is classified into three types - embryonal, alveolar, and pleomorphic. Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common type.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with PTCH gene mutation?
questions.solution:
Gorlin syndrome, also known as nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome, has an autosomal dominant inheritance with mutation of PATCHED (PTCH1) gene.

It consists of the following features:

  • Multiple Basal cell carcinomas
  • Highly characteristic facies (with large forehead)
  • Bifid or misshapen ribs
  • Vertebral and other skeletal anomalies
  • Pits of the skin of the palms and soles
  • Dysgenesis of the corpus callosum
  • Calcification of the falx cerebri (at an earlier age than is seen in non‐affected individuals)
  • Macrocephaly.

Option A: Muir-Torre syndrome- defect in DNA mismatch repair genes (MLH-1 or MSH-2) and microsatellite instability

Option C: Rombo syndrome- autosomal dominant syndrome with basal cell carcinoma as prominent feature; defective gene unidentified

Option D: Cowden syndrome- PTEN (phosphatase and tensin homologue) mutation

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented with fatigue and weight loss. On examination, pallor and splenomegaly were noted. Peripheral blood smear examination findings are shown in the image. Which of the following BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors is not a first-line agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the peripheral smear findings (increased WBCs with myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms), is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Bosutinib is approved for use in this condition only for resistant and/or intolerant cases and not in newly diagnosed cases.

Agents that can be used as first-line for CML are:

  • Imatinib
  • Dasatinib
  • Nilotinib 

Dasatinib and nilotinib can be used in newly diagnosed cases of CML, that are found to be imatinib-resistant.

questions.text: As a medical officer involved in the sentinel surveillance for HIV under the National AIDS Control Programme, your duties include all of the following except:

choices.text: Estimation of total infection in the community
Estimation of total cases in hospitals

questions.solution:
As a medical officer involved in the sentinel surveillance, the estimation of total cases in hospitals is not included in the sentinel surveillance for HIV under National AIDS Control Programme (NACO).

The aims of the HIV sentinel surveillance include:

  • Determine the level of HIV infection in the community.
  • Understand the trends of HIV epidemic.
  • Understand the geographical spread of HIV infection and classify districts according to epidemiological and vulnerability criteria.

These objectives are achieved by conducting annual cross-sectional surveys of the risk group in the same geographical place.

questions.text: An ultrasound abdomen done for evaluation of flank pain in a man revealed a large mass arising from the right kidney. CECT abdomen done showed the presence of a central stellate scar. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the presence of a central stellate scar on CECT is suggestive of a diagnosis of oncocytoma.

Oncocytoma is the most common benign renal tumor. It arises from cells rich in mitochondria. Familial type is associated with Birt Hogg Dube syndrome. Most patients remain asymptomatic even with large oncocytomas. In some cases, it may present as an abdominal lump.

The cystic variant of the tumor is classified as Bosniak class III on CECT. On histological examination, large eosinophilic cells owing to an abundance of mitochondria are seen arranged in distinct nests. Partial nephrectomy is the preferred treatment. 

Note: Central stellate scar on CECT is also seen in chromophobe RCC and focal nodular hyperplasia of the liver.

The given CECT shows an enhancing right renal mass with a central stellate scar

The given slide shows large eosinophilic cells arranged in nests

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, with oliguria for 3 days. He also complained of feeling drowsy and confused while working. He also complains of episodes of breathlessness and chest pain. On examination, swelling around the eyes and both ankles was noticed. RFT was done and serum creatinine was found to be 2.28 mg/dl(Normal 0.7-1.3 mg/dl). A diagnosis of AKI was made. The patient comes under AKI staging ______.
questions.solution:
The patient comes under acute kidney injury stage 1 of the KDIGO classification as the serum creatinine is increased 1.75 times the normal value.

KDIGO criteria classify AKI on the basis of an increase in serum creatinine and/or decrease in urinary output.

  • Stage 1 – Increase in serum creatinine to 1.5 to 1.9 times baseline, or increase in serum creatinine by ≥0.3 mg/dL or reduction in urine output to <0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6 to 12 hours.
  • Stage 2 – Increase in serum creatinine to 2.0 to 2.9 times baseline, or reduction in urine output to <0.5 mL/kg/hour for ≥12 hours.
  • Stage 3 – Increase in serum creatinine to 3.0 times baseline, or increase in serum creatinine to ≥ 4.0 mg/dL or reduction in urine output to <0.3 mL/kg/hour for ≥24 hours, or anuria for ≥12 hours, or the initiation of renal replacement therapy.

questions.text: Capsular polysaccharide constitutes an important virulence factor responsible for protective antibody response. In which among the following bacteria is the protective response not due to capsular polysaccharide?
questions.solution:
Among the given bacteria, the protective response in Bordetella pertussis is not due to capsular polysaccharides.

Bordetella pertussis is a gram-negative coccobacillus. It produces various virulence factors and toxins that are responsible for the clinical disease.

  • Pertussis toxin causes lymphocytosis, sensitization to histamine, and enhanced insulin secretion. It can be toxoided and the toxoid form is a major component of acellular pertusis vaccines. 
  • Filamentous hemagglutinin(FHA) promotes adherence of the B.pertussis to the cilia of respiratory tract and erythrocytes. It also has a hemagglutinin activity. 
  • Pertactin is an outer membrane protein (OMP) antigen present in all virulent strains. It is part of acellular pertusis vaccines and antibody to pertactin is seen in blood after immunization or infection in children
  • Tracheal cytotoxin causes destruction of the ciliated cells in the trachea. 
  • Other virulence factors- Includes Adenylate cyclase, heat-labile toxin, lipopolysaccharide.

Capsulated bacteria include:-

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Several groups of streptococci
  • Neisseria meningitides
  • Klebsiella
  • Haemophilus influenza
  • Yersinia
  • Bacillus

questions.text: Which of the following antiglaucoma drug is unsafe in infants ?
questions.solution:
Brimonidine and apraclonidine can cause CNS depression and apnea in neonates and are contraindicated in children below 2 years.

questions.text:
Which of the following mode of inheritances is seen in Ehler–Danlos syndrome?
  1. Autosomal dominant
  2. Autosomal recessive
  3. Mitochondrial
  4. X-linked dominant
  5. Genomic imprinting
questions.solution:
The mode of inheritance of Ehler–Danlos syndrome (EDS) encompasses two Mendelian patterns, namely:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Autosomal recessive

The biosynthesis of collagen can be disturbed by genetic errors that may affect any one of the numerous structural collagen genes or enzymes necessary for posttranscriptional modifications of collagen. Such molecular heterogeneity results in the expression of EDS as a clinically variable disorder, with varied patterns of inheritance.

questions.text: A patient presented with 6 weeks of amenorrhoea and a positive UPT. TVS revealed a tubal ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following findings can be usually picked up on colour Doppler?

choices.text: Enhanced blood flow pattern in the uterine artery

questions.solution:
Ring of fire pattern is seen on color doppler in a tubal ectopic pregnancy. This is due to placental blood flow in the tubal pregnancy. 

This finding may also be seen in corpus luteum cysts but the wall is less echogenic compared to tubal ectopic.

Option A: There is an enhanced blood flow pattern outside the uterine cavity in case of ectopic pregnancy.

Option B: Arias-Stella reaction/phenomenon is a histological finding. It is an atypical endometrial change due to the action of progesterone on the endometrial tissue seen in normal, ectopic, and molar pregnancies.

On histology, there are:

  • large cells with abundant eosinophilic or vacuolated cytoplasm
  • nuclear enlargement
  • hyperchromasia

Option D: Whirlpool sign refers to the twisted ovarian pedicle seen on USG of ovarian torsion.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Six’s thermometer.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the first-trimester ultrasound?

choices.text: A gestational sac can first be seen 4 weeks after LMP
Accuracy of USG dating decreases after the 1st trimester
Yolk sac is the first sign of pregnancy on USG
A normal gestational sac implants in the midline of the endometrial cavity

questions.solution:
The accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound is the highest in the first trimester and decreases afterwards.

Option A: Gestational sac is reliably seen at 5 weeks of gestation on transvaginal sonography(TVS).

Option C: The first sign of pregnancy seen on sonography is the gestational sac. Visualisation of the yolk sac within the gestational sac confirms an intrauterine location for pregnancy. 

Option D: A normal gestational sac implants eccentrically in the endometrium, whereas a pseudosac is seen in the midline of the endometrial cavity.

questions.text: A patient has presented to you with a burn wound as seen in the image below. With regards to Jackson's zones of tissue injury, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Area 2 is the most severely burned portion
The outer area of a burn is called the zone of hyperemia
Vasodilation is seen in the area 3
Area 1 heals with minimal or no scarring

questions.solution:
Vasoconstriction (not vasodilation) is seen in red region or zone of stasis (marked zone 3).

Jackson zones of tissue injury following burns has three zones:

  • The zone of coagulation is the most severely burned portion and is typically in the center of the wound.
  • Peripheral to that is a zone of stasis, with variable degrees of vasoconstriction and resultant ischemia.
  • The last, outermost area of a burn is called the zone of hyperemia, which will heal with minimal or no scarring and is most like a superficial or first-degree burn. It is characterized by vasodilation from inflammation surrounding the burn wound.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with a history of persistent low mood for the past 3 years. He also complains of fatigue and insomnia during this period. He gives a history of worsening low mood over the past 3 weeks, along with suicidal thoughts and a loss of interest in all activities.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Double depression is the most probable diagnosis in this scenario. Dysthymia and major depressive disorder in the same period constitute double depression. 

From the given history:

  • Features of low mood, fatigue, and insomnia for more than 2 years point towards dysthymia.
  • Features of low mood, fatigue, insomnia, anhedonia, and suicidal thoughts for more than 2 weeks point towards major depressive disorder.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following tumors are best treated with radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Seminoma is a highly radiosensitive tumor and is best managed with radiotherapy, in contrast to melanoma, osteosarcoma and pancreatic carcinoma, which are known to be resistant to radiation therapy.

  • Pancreatic carcinoma

questions.text: What is the most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
The cells are most radiosensitive in the G2-M phase of the cell cycle. 

This is because the cells lack sufficient time to repair DNA damage before division in the G2-M phase, leading to mitotic catastrophe. 

Radiosensitivity gradually decreases from G1 to the early S phase and is the least in the late S phase, where homologous recombination repair is most active after DNA replication.

questions.text: Carbonic anhydrase is present at all places except
questions.solution:
• The  carbonic anhydrases  are a family of enzymes that   catalyze   the rapid interconversion  of  carbon dioxide and water to bicarbonate end protons (or vice versa). The  active site of most carbonic anhydrases contains a zinc ion; they are therefore classified as  metalloenzymes.
  • One of the functions of the enzyme in animals is to interconvert carbon dioxide and bicarbonate to maintain acid-base balance in blood and other tissues, and to help transport carbon dioxide out of tissues.
  • Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme  found  in red blood cells, gastric mucosa, pancreatic cells, and renal tubules that catalyzes the interconversion of carbon dioxide and carbonic acid.
  • Carbonic anhydrase is not present in plasma.

questions.text: A 1 year old child presents with features of hypotonia. On examination , he has tongue fasciculations, normal intelligence , keeps his body in a frog like position. The most likely diagnosis would be
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests Floppy Infant syndrome.

Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disease characterized by progressive degeneration of anterior horn cells, which results in weakness.

Among the causes of Floppy Infant syndrome, Spinal muscular atrophy is the best choice as:

  • Intelligence is normal
  • Tongue fasciculations

Other options :

  • Down’s syndrtome – Intelligence impaired
  • Guillian barre – Acute condition with history of fever or viral infections.

questions.text: During immunohistochemistry for ER, PR status, staining of what percentage of cells indicates positivity?
questions.solution: The staining of ≥1% of cells is considered positive. Expression of estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) in breast cancer cells is mainly assessed by immunohistochemistry.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to OPD with complaints of pain over the forearm. On detailed examination, several wounds with cigarettes burns are found. X-ray showed a spiral fracture of the radius. Which of the following is least likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Multiple injuries at same stage of healing

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of battered baby syndrome. The classical feature of this condition is injuries inflicted are of different ages and in different stages of healing. This is due to the repetitive nature of child abuse.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

This syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury varies with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, failure to thrive, soft tissue swelling or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine

questions.text: What is the predominant inheritance pattern of sideroblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Inherited forms of sideroblastic anemia are usually X-linked. Rarely, autosomal recessive forms may also occur.

X-linked sideroblastic anemia results from the deficient activity of the erythroid form of ALA-synthase (ALA-synthase 2) and is associated with ineffective erythropoiesis

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with generalized weakness and lightheadedness for 2 weeks. Blood investigations were notable for decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH. Her peripheral smear showed RBC fragments. Which vitamin deficiency is associated with the above presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with fatigue and decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. It is associated with a deficiency of vitamin E.

The most important function of vitamin E is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. Vitamin E inhibits lipid peroxidation by free radicals, thereby stabilizing cell membranes. Hence, its deficiency can result in erythrocyte membranes being abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia.

Note: Vitamin K deficiency does not cause hemolysis. It causes manifestations of impaired coagulation, such as easy bruisability, mucosal bleeding, etc. However, vitamin K toxicity can cause hemolysis.

questions.text: Serial chest X-rays of an elderly man reveal progressive massive fibrosis. Which of the following pneumoconiosis is associated with this?
questions.solution:
Progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) is associated with anthracosis. PMF classically develops in anthracosis and silicosis.

Exposure to coal dust causes progressive lung injury called anthracosis. Initially, it manifests as simple coal worker pneumoconiosis, which occurs after exposure for 10–12 years and is reversible. Later, it can progress to progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) which is irreversible.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of events that occur during necrosis?

1) Cell swelling
2) Karyolysis
3) Karyorrhexis
4) Pyknosis
questions.solution:
The sequence of events in necrosis is: cellular swelling → pyknosis → karyorrhexis → karyolysis

Necrosis is defined as the spectrum of morphological changes that follow cell death due to the progressive degradative action of enzymes.

Morphological changes that occur in necrosis are as follows:

Cytoplasmic changes -

  • Increased eosinophilic staining on H&E specimens
  • Moth-eaten appearance of the cytoplasm - due vacuolated cytoplasmic organelles formed by enzymatic degradation
  • Glassy and homogenous cytoplasm - due to loss of glycogen in the cytoplasm

Nuclear changes -

  • Pyknosis - nucleus first shrinks and becomes more condensed
  • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus
  • Karyolysis - nucleus fades away leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells

questions.text: You see a resident use the following instrument to grasp the anterior lip of the cervix in a patient posted for a vaginal hysterectomy. What is this instrument known as?
questions.solution:
The image shows vulsellum forceps. It is used to grasp the cervical lip and steady the cervix during vaginal surgery. It is a long instrument with a gentle curve so that the line of vision is not obstructed.

Option A: Allis forceps can be identified by continuous teeth, equal on both ends. It is used to hold structures with a firm grip.

Option C: Kocher's artery forceps are non-traumatic with a single tooth at the tip. They help in achieving hemostasis by firm pressure.

Option D: Lahey's tissue grasping forceps has teeth similar to dinner forks. They are used to hold fibrous tissue and they give a firm grip without slippage.

questions.text: The fundus is wrapped (270 degrees) around the posterior aspect of the esophagus in which of the following corrective procedures for GERD?
questions.solution:
Partial posterior fundoplication between 180 to 270 degrees is called Toupet fundoplication.

It is used in the surgical management of GERD. Partial anterior fundoplication is Dor’s fundoplication and total fundoplication is Nissen’s fundoplication.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA polymerase I?

choices.text: It is involved in the creation of okazaki fragments.
It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis.

questions.solution:
The true statement is that DNA polymerase I (pol I) is found in prokaryotes.

The prokaryotic polymerases are DNA polymerases I, II, and III. DNA polymerase I recognize a “nick” or break in the phosphate backbone, and then removes each RNA primer and fills the gaps with DNA. It does this through its 5'→3' exonuclease activity. It has DNA repair activity through 3'→5' exonuclease activity. DNA polymerase II carries out DNA proofreading and repair. DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme for the synthesis of the leading strand of DNA. 

Option A: DNA polymerase δ (eukaryotic polymerase) synthesizes Okazaki fragments which are short, newly synthesized DNA fragments that are formed on the lagging template strand during DNA replication. They are complementary to the lagging template strand.
Option C: Primase synthesizes RNA primers to start the replication.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

Prokaryotic DNA replication enzymes and their function:

Enzyme Function
DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair
DNA polymerase III (Pol III)

Processive, leading strand synthesis, DNA proofreading
DnaG

Primase 
Helicase ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA.
Primase Initiates synthesis of RNA primers.
Topoisomerase Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.
Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA.
DNA ligase Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.

 

Eukaryotic DNA polymerases:

Eukaryotic DNA Polymerases Functions Proofreading
α  Primase (initiates DNA synthesis) -
β DNA repair -

γ

 Mitochondrial DNA synthesis +
 δ  Processive, lagging strand synthesis(forms and elongates Okazaki fragments from primer) +
 ε  Processive, leading strand synthesis +

questions.text: The anterior pituitary develops from ______
questions.solution: Anterior pituitary or adenohypophysis of pituitary develops from Rathke's pouch which is an ectodermal diverticulum of the primitive oral cavity.

questions.text: All are tumor-like lesions except _______.
questions.solution:
Aneurysmal bone cyst, eosinophilic granuloma, and monostotic fibrous dysplasia are tumour-like lesions. Enchondroma falls under the category of cartilage forming tumors. 

WHO classification of bone tumors:

  • Bone forming tumors
  • Cartilage forming tumors
  • Giant cell tumors
  • Marrow tumors
  • Vascular tumors
  • Tumor-like lesions

Tumor-like lesions:

  • Simple and aneurysmal bone cyst
  • Fibrous dysplasia (Mono and polyostotic)
  • Reparative giant cell granuloma
  • Fibrous cortical defect
  • Eosinophilic granuloma

questions.text: Hollenhorst plaques are seen in _______.
questions.solution:
Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal arterial occlusion (CRAO). 

They are cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. They originate from atherosclerotis plaques in larger arteries. The image below shows Hollenhorst plaques (arrow).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is usually avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides has to be avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis. It blocks Ca2+ mediated exocytosis of acetylcholine from the presynaptic membrane in the neuromuscular junction. The decrease in ACh levels aggravates myasthenia gravis. 

Aminoglycosides can also have a direct inhibitory effect on post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors. 

Drugs that may aggravate myasthenia gravis are

  • Antibiotics like aminoglycosides, quinolones, and macrolides
  • Beta-blockers
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Local anesthetics
  • Magnesium
  • Non–depolarising muscle relaxants
  • Penicillamine
  • Quinine derivatives

questions.text: The organism which cannot be grown on artificial media is:
questions.solution:
Rhinosporidum seeberi cannot be grown on artificial media; however, it grows in vivo in epithelial carcinoma cell culture lines.

Non cultivable fungi – Pneumocystis jirovecii and Locazia.

questions.text: Which intrinsic ocular muscle has a parasympathetic innervation?
questions.solution:
The intrinsic ocular muscle supplied by parasympathetic innervation is the sphincter pupillae.

1. Parasympathetic innervation:

  • Sphincter pupillae: Short ciliary nerve–Ciliary ganglion
  • Ciliary muscle–Accessory ganglion 

2. Sympathetic innervation: Dilator pupillae and Muller’s muscle

3. Motor Supply:

  • 3rd nerve: All extraocular muscles (except the 2 given below)
  • 6th nerve: Lateral rectus (LR6)
  • 4th nerve: Superior oblique (SO4)
  • 7th nerve: Orbicularis oculi

Related Pearl: Sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve supply to iris muscles

  • Dilator pupillae/radial muscle of iris: Sympathetic postganglionic nerves from cervical ganglion.
  • Constrictor pupillae/circular muscle of iris: Parasympathetic postganglionic nerves from ciliary ganglion (Edinger Westphal nucleus).

questions.text:
Which of the following are the roles of lncRNAs (long non-coding RNAs)?
i.	Promoting gene activation
ii.	Preventing gene transcription
iii.	Scaffolding
iv.	Modifying histones and DNA
questions.solution:
All of the above are functions of long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs).

  • lncRNAs are a large and diverse class of regulatory non-coding RNA molecules that are transcribed from the non-protein-coding regions of the chromosomes, but are not translated into proteins.
  • Unlike microRNAs (miRNAs), lncRNAs have diverse roles, which includes, but is not limited to, the regulation of gene expression, protein synthesis, scaffolding, etc.

The following are the various roles of lncRNAs:

  • Gene activation (signaling): lncRNAs can promote gene activation by facilitating the binding of the transcription factors.
  • Prevention of gene transcription (decoy): This may occur due to the binding of lncRNAs to the transcription factors.
  • Histone and DNA modification (guides): lncRNAs may direct the action of acetylases and methylases (or deacetylases and demethylases), thus regulating the modification of histones and DNA.
  • Scaffolding: lncRNAs may promote the assembly of protein complexes and promote scaffolding, thereby enabling the stabilization of secondary or tertiary structures and/or multi-subunit complexes that influence general chromatin architecture or gene activity.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency with symptoms of unstable angina. ECG done in pain-free interval showed biphasic T waves in precordial leads without ST changes. Cardiac troponins were normal. Coronary angiography revealed stenosis of the proximal left anterior descending artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Wellens syndrome. It is alternatively known as anterior, descending, T-wave syndrome. The ECG pattern of Wellens syndrome is relatively common in patients who exhibit symptoms consistent with unstable angina. 

ECG in the pain-free interval is characterized by deeply inverted or biphasic T waves in precordial leads and with minimal or no ST elevations. Cardiac enzymes are normal or mildly elevated.

These patients are at high risk for impending large anterior wall acute myocardial infarction.

The ECG below shows biphasic T waves in leads V2 and V3 and inverted T waves in leads V4 and V5 in Wellens syndrome. 

Option A: Broken heart syndrome is another name for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Option C: Barlow syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse.

Option D: Brugada syndrome is a genetic cardiac rhythm disorder.

questions.text: A 10 month old child presents with 2 weeks history of fever, vomiting and alteration of sensorium. Cranial CT scan reveals basal exudates and hydrocephalus, the most likely etiological agent is
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests tuberculous meningitis.

Characteristic features are:

  • Insidious onset of fever
  • Raised ICT
  • Basal exudates and Hydrocephalus on CT scan

questions.text: Which of the following should be monitored if linezolid is given for more than 14 days?
questions.solution:
Linezolid use is associated with thrombocytopenia in >2% of patients. The occurrence is related to duration of treatment.

Platelet counts should be monitored in patients receiving linezolid beyond 2 weeks and in patients with risk of thrombocytopenia irrespective of the duration of treatment.

Note: Linezolid is associated with nephrotoxicity but the incidence is very rare. Linezolid and it's metabolites are not overt nephrotoxic agents that require regular RFT monitoring.

questions.text: A young lady has been on treatment for autoimmune hepatitis for 2 weeks, she has now come for follow-up investigations. Which of the following suggests a poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Persistently increased serum bilirubin after 2 weeks of therapy suggests a poor prognosis.

Early signs of poor prognosis include:

  • Failure of serum bilirubin to reduce after 2 weeks of therapy.

Early signs of good prognosis include:

  • An increase in serum albumin.
  • A decrease in serum bilirubin, globulins and aminotransferases.
  • Improvement of symptoms.

Histopathologic improvement can often take months to years.

questions.text: A child presents with multiple painless swellings over the costochondral junction. Which of the following conditions is least likely in this child?
questions.solution:
Multiple painless swellings at the costochondral junction is suggestive of rachitic rosary in this child. It is not seen in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Rachitic rosary is seen in rickets and all the conditions leading to hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia. Hemangiopericytoma causes hypophosphataemic vitamin D-resistant rickets.

questions.text: A young woman with fertility issues is diagnosed to have genital tuberculosis. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: The causative agent is Mycobacterium bovis
It generally occurs secondary to a primary focus
It commonly presents as a unilateral condition

questions.solution:
Genital tuberculosis is a bilateral condition. 

It can be caused by both Mycobacterium tuberculosis (95% cases) and Mycobacterium bovis (5% cases). It almost always occurs secondary to a primary focus elsewhere in the body. The most common primary focus is lungs > lymph nodes > abdomen > generalised miliary infection.

It mostly spreads hematogenously. Lymphatic spread is also seen sometimes. It can rarely spread by direct contact with the affected intraabdominal organs or peritoneum. 

The fallopian tubes are the first to be affected. The disease subsequently spreads to other genital organs and the peritoneum. This is followed by the involvement of bilateral pelvic lymph nodes. Vulvovaginal involvement is usually secondary to uterine involvement.

The most common presentation of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group is infertility.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is described as emotionally cold and self-absorbed. He likes to stay alone, detached from social relationships, and prefers solitary activities. What type of personality disorder is this?
questions.solution:
A young male who is alone by choice and emotionally cold comes under schizoid personality.

Schizoid personality is a markedly detached person, stays alone in introspection, and lives in his own fantasy world. This is associated with having a cold attitude.

questions.text: While assisting a laparoscopic appendectomy, you observe the resident use the Fold of Treves as a guide while coagulating vessels in the mesoappendix. Which of the following best describes the anatomical landmark?

choices.text: Mucous membrane projecting into the ileal lumen
The ilio-cecal fold of the peritoneum
The fold of the mucous membrane around appendiceal orifice
The fold of the peritoneum over ascending colon

questions.solution:
Fold of Treves is an antimesenteric ileocecal fold of peritoneum. 

A clinical aid useful for detecting the location of the appendix through small abdominal incisions is the identification of the fold of Treves. It marks the junction of the ileum and cecum. As it does not contain any vessel, it is referred to as the bloodless fold of Treves. It is also used as a guide to determine the extent of coagulation during an appendectomy. This prevents thermal injury to adjacent structures.

Jackson Membrane: Adhesion from the right abdominal wall to the anterior tenia of the ascending colon.

Gerlach valves: A mucosal fold covering the appendiceal orifice.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with acute onset fever and dysuria. Urinalysis reveals plenty of leukocytes with glycosuria. A CT scan of the abdomen is performed, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, along with the CT scan showing an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection, is suggestive of left-sided emphysematous pyelonephritis.

Emphysematous pyelonephritis is a severe, acute, necrotizing infection of the kidney caused by gas-producing organisms. It predominantly affects diabetic patients who are particularly susceptible due to their hyperglycemic state, which promotes bacterial growth and fermentation. The most common causative organism is Escherichia coli, which ferments sugar to produce carbon dioxide, leading to gas accumulation within renal parenchyma or perinephric tissues. Less commonly, organisms like Klebsiella and Proteus species can also cause this condition.  

Almost all patients present with fever, vomiting and flank pain. Patients frequently present with sepsis and ketoacidosis. If not treated early, it may lead to fulminant sepsis and is associated with high mortality. 

The diagnosis is primarily established radiographically, with a CT scan being the investigation of choice in identifying the extent of the emphysematous process and guiding management. The following diagnostic features are seen:

  • Enlarged, destructed renal parenchyma
  • Small bubbly or linear streaks of gas
  • Fluid collections, with gas-fluid levels
  • Focal necrotic areas with or without abscess

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease is brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He has been neglecting symptoms of dizziness and palpitations for the past few days. His ECG is given below. The most possible diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of ventricular fibrillation. 

The features in the above ECG that support the diagnosis are:

  • Disordered electrical ventricular activation with no identifiable QRS complexes
  • No identifiable P-waves, no PR interval

Possible mechanisms of ventricular fibrillation include spiral wave reentry and multiple circulating reentry wavefronts.

The ECG features suggestive of ventricular tachycardia are as follows:

  • Wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology (marked with red arrows in image below)
  • Absence of the P waves
  • Rate >100/min- in the ECG below, it is ~180 beats/min (1500/no. of small boxes between two R waves)

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the education index used for calculating the HDI?

choices.text: It includes expected years of schooling
Adult literacy rate is not considered
Minimum and maximum values are based on global data

questions.solution:
The gross enrollment ratio is no longer used in obtaining the education index in HDI. It was used as an indicator earlier.

The education index is calculated by taking into account the mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling. Maximum and minimum values are based on global data.

Adult literacy rate and gross enrollment ratio were used as indicators before 2009.  

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text: A 42-year-old man in the nephrology ward has a GFR of less than 30mL/min, suggestive of severe renal failure. What is the best drug that can be given to him?
questions.solution:
Metolazone is effective in severe renal failure (GFR<30ml/min).

Metolazone works primarily in the distal convoluted tubule, rather than the proximal convoluted tubule, and has little effect on GFR and can hence be used in patients with a reduced GFR. Indapamide is another thiazide diuretic that may be effective in severe renal failure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with a scrotal swelling. On examination, the testis is felt separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant, as shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a transilluminant scrotal swelling palpated apart from normal testes is suggestive of an epididymal cyst. 

An epididymal cyst is a multilocular cyst formed due to is the cystic degeneration of the epididymis. Multiple cysts formed posterior to the epididymis can feel like a bunch of grapes on palpation. Due to the presence of crystal clear fluid, an epididymal cyst brilliantly transilluminates and has a Chinese lantern appearance.

The image shows the Chinese lantern appearance on transillumination:


It can be differentiated from a hydrocele, where the testis is not separately palpable.

Option A: Varicoceles present with dragging discomfort in the scrotum on standing and characteristic ‘bag of worms’ feel on palpation. 

Option C: Spermatocele is a unilocular transluminant retention cyst formed at the epididymal head. Due to the presence of spermatozoa, barley-water fluid is seen. Although transilluminant, the cyst does not have a Chinese lantern appearance.

Option D: Chyloceles are formed due to the rupture of lymphatic varix and the discharge of chyle into the hydrocele. Fluid rich in cholesterol is seen and the swelling is not transilluminant.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A patient with gastric carcinoma develops proximal muscle weakness. Biopsy findings are suggestive of dermatomyositis. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed paraneoplastic dermatomyositis. Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic dermatomyositis and juvenile dermatomyositis.

It presents as gradual, symmetric muscle weakness and myalgias, typically affecting the proximal muscles first. Fine movements controlled by distal muscles are affected late in the disease. Myopathic changes and elevation in serum creatine kinase levels suggest muscle damage.

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: Coronary artery dominance is based on the origin of which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Coronary artery dominance is based on the origin of posterior descending artery (PDA) also called posterior interventricular artery.

Coronary artery dominance

  • Coronary artery dominance is based on the origin of posterior descending artery (PDA) also called posterior interventricular artery.
  • In ‘right dominance’, PDA is derived from RCA.
  • In ‘left dominance’ it is derived from the LCA.
  • In the so-called ‘balanced’ pattern, branches of both arteries run in or near the posterior interventricular groove.
  • RCA is dominant in >80% of patients.
  • The term coronary artery dominance is misleading because LCA almost always supplies a greater volume of tissue than RCA.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of testicular torsion?

choices.text: Presence of remnant of mullerian duct
Pedicle between epididymis and body of testis

questions.solution:
High investment of the tunica vaginalis is the most common cause of torsion of testis. It causes the testes to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause of testicular torsion in adolescents.

Bell clapper testes are typically bilateral. The image below shows the bell-clapper deformity of the testes:

Other abnormalities that cause torsion of the testes:

  • Inversion of the testis: The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.

  • Pedicle between epididymis and body of testis: Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis by a pedicle allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.

An appendix testis is a small vestigial appendage located on the upper pole of the testis. Twisting of the appendage causes testicular appendix torsion. In it, a classic blue dot sign is seen on the upper pole of the testis. It is seen as a hard tender nodule with a blue discoloration on the superior aspect of the testis. This is a remnant of the Mullerian duct, that regresses on development.

The image below shows the blue dot sign on the testis:

Note: This is a controversial question.

The latest edition of Bailey and Love 27th edition, page no 1500, lists high investment of the tunica vaginalis as the most common cause of torsion of testes. On the other hand, the 26th edition, page no 1379, lists inversion of testes as the most common cause. There is no consensus among other books. Therefore, according to the most updated version of Bailey and Love, the most common cause of torsion testes is high investment of the tunica vaginalis.

questions.text: What is the area from which water drains into impounding reservoirs known as?
questions.solution:
The area draining into the impounding reservoirs are known as catchment areas.

Impounding reservoirs are also called embankment ponds. These reservoirs are artificial lake-like water bodies. They are made by building an embankment or earth fill in an area into which natural water flows and can be stored for usage. Dams are also built to create these reservoirs.

Water from these reservoirs is second in purity to rainwater but is not completely free from impurities. Catchment areas are the main sources of impurities in the water in impounding reservoirs.

The image given below shows catchment area:

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with involuntary, sudden jerking movements of both upper limbs. They occur most frequently in the morning after awakening and are provoked by a lack of sleep. EEG demonstrates bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow- wave discharges. Which of the following features is not seen in this type of seizure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myoclonic seizures. Post-ictal paralysis is not seen in these seizures.

Myoclonic seizures are characterized by preserved consciousness (rarely very short loss of consciousness), preserved postural control, Lack of postictal confusion.

Myoclonic seizures usually coexist with other forms of generalized seizures but are the predominant feature of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). The EEG shows bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow wave discharges. 

JME or Janz's syndrome is an epilepsy syndrome that has familial inheritance and begins in adolescence. It most commonly occurs in the morning and is provoked by sleep deprivation. JME is usually associated with GTCS and sometimes with absence seizures. EEG shows a typical 4-6 Hz polyspike and wave pattern. Treatment includes administration of sodium valproate.

questions.text: A researcher wanted to calculate the mean age of onset of type II diabetes mellitus in a population. He got a sample mean of 45. To measure the extent of deviation from the population mean, which of the following should he use?
questions.solution:
The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population means.

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with complaints of severe abdominal pain. On examination, his vitals are stable and there is abdominal rigidity and tenderness. The erect X-ray of the abdomen is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum and the patient is posted for emergency laparotomy. It reveals the presence of a perforated type I gastric ulcer. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Perform distal gastrectomy with Billroth I anastomosis
Closure of the perforation with Graham's patch repair

questions.solution:
In stable patients without operative risks, Perforated type I gastric ulcers are best managed by distal gastrectomy with Billroth I anastomosis (with or without vagotomy).       

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable or unfit for surgery, simple patch repair with biopsy preferred.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      

Type of Gastric Ulcer Management
Type I  Distal gastrectomy 
 Type II and III Distal gastrectomy + Vagotomy
 Type IV

 

 Csendes procedure

 or

 Pauchet procedure

 or

 Kelling - Madlener procedure

questions.text: Which chromosome contains the genes that determine the A and B blood groups?
questions.solution:
The genes that determine the A and B blood groups are located on chromosome 9. The phenotypes are expressed in the Mendelian codominant manner.

Rh genes determining Rh blood grouping are present on chromosome 1.

questions.text: Prolonged stimulation of GPCR leads to down-regulation. This event is initiated by___

choices.text: Regulators of G protein signalling (RGS) proteins

questions.solution:
On prolonged stimulation of GPCR, down-regulation is initiated by G protein receptor kinases (GRKs)

  • GRKs phosphorylate the C terminal tail of GPCR.
  • Results in the recruitment of proteins called arrestin.
  • Arrestin binds to the GPCR receptor on the internal surface displacing G proteins and inhibiting signaling.

option a: Regulators of G protein signaling (RGS) proteins function is to enhance the GTPase activity of alpha subunit.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a high-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste?
questions.solution:
Microwaving is a low-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste.

The heating systems used for the treatment and disposal of biomedical waste are:

Low-heat system High-heat system

Autoclaving: Uses steam. It is of two types-

  1. Gravity flow autoclave 
  2. Vacuum autoclave

Microwaving: Uses moist heat and steam generated by microwave energy

Incineration: Waste is destroyed/denatured under high temperatures 

Plasma pyrolysis: Waste is treated at high temperatures under controlled conditions to form gases that are subjected to combustion in the secondary chamber

Hydroclaving: The waste is subjected to indirect heating by applying steam to the outer jacket

Dry heat sterilization: Waste sharps are treated using dry heat at a temperature >185 C for 150 minutes

questions.text: What is the normal value of y/x in the following representation?
questions.solution:
In the above image, y/x denotes the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall. This is called as Reid index and it is normally 0.4. 

It is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows:

  • Hypersecretion of mucus
  • Hypertrophy of submucosal glands
  • Goblet-cell hyperplasia
  • Inflammation
Difference between clinical presentation of emphysema and chronic bronchitis:
