questions.text: Which of the following autonomic disorders do not involve the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Syringobulbia is a condition that affects the brainstem, not the spinal cord. It is a neurological disorder characterized by a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) which affects the brainstem (medulla).

The following autonomic disorders are associated with spinal cord involvement:

  • Syringomyelia
  • Multiple sclerosis and neuromyelitis optica
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
  • Traumatic quadriplegia
  • Subacute combined degeneration
  • Tetanus
  • Stiff-person syndrome
  • Spinal cord tumors

questions.text: A 1-month-old male infant is brought to the OPD with vomiting. History suggests a usage of maternal erythromycin. A USG abdomen was done and is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the USG showing cervix sign and nipple sign is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS).

CHPS is associated with hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus resulting in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. It is common between 3-6 weeks of age. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. Maternal intake of macrolide antibiotics during pregnancy has been associated with an increased risk of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) in infants.

Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. The characteristic metabolic abnormality is hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to recurrent vomiting. 

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. The following findings may be seen:

  • The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm
  • The nipple sign is produced by the double-layered hypertrophic mucosa that protrudes into the stomach 
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is therefore called the cervix sign.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the casualty with a 24-hour history of fever, sore throat, and diffuse erythematous macular rash. Past history is positive for unprotected intercourse with a new partner. What is true about the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute HIV syndrome. The virus is transmissible during this early infection period.

It is characterized by acute burst of viremia and wide virus dissemination and seeding of lymphoid organs (e.g., gut-associated lymphoid tissue), culminating in the destruction of CD4+ cells. 

The p24 antigen capture assay is used as a screening test for HIV infection in patients suspected of having the acute HIV syndrome.

Option A: The incubation period for acute HIV syndrome is around 3 to 6 weeks.

Option B: The acute HIV syndrome is typical of an acute viral syndrome and is very similar to acute infectious mononucleosis. The clinical findings include fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy. Rash, headache, arthralgia, and anorexia/weight loss can also be seen.

Option D: Opportunistic infections can occur during this stage of infection, reflecting the immunodeficiency that results from reduced numbers of CD4+T cells.

questions.text: Cultures of synovial fluid may guide antibiotic therapy in:
questions.solution:
True gonococcal septic arthritis is less common than the DGI syndrome and always follows DGI.

A single joint such as hip, knee, ankle or wrist is usually involved.

Synovial fluid which contains more than 50,000 leucocytes per microlitre can be obtained easily unlike in cases of DGI but cultures of synovial fluid are positive in less than 50 % of cases only.

questions.text: At 2 am in the casualty, the police brought a rape victim who has alleged that a colleague drugged her at a party. She cannot recollect events of the night clearly. Which of the following would you specifically include in her urine test?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is referred to as a date rape drug.

Date rape drugs:

  • Ketamine
  • Gamma hydroxyl butyrate
  • Flunitrazepam (Rohypnol)

Date rape drugs produce disorienting and sedating effects as a result of which the victim does not remember part or entire episode while under the influence of the drug.

questions.text: Morphological appearance of Pneumocystis jiroveci infection of lung is best characterized by:-

choices.text: ARDS with wide spread hyaline membrane formation
Interstitial pneumonitis with foamy intra alveolar exudates

questions.solution:
Morphological features of Pneumocystis jirovecii:-

The multiplication of the fungus in the lungs induces a hyaline or foamy alveolar exudate. In stained sections, the exudate filling the alveoli shows a characteristic honeycomb pattern. Chest radiographs may be normal or show diffuse interstitial infiltrates.

questions.text: A diabetic primigravida is suspected to have cephalopelvic disproportion. What should her obstetric conjugate be for a trial of labor to be conducted?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, a trial of labor or vaginal delivery can be allowed if the obstetric conjugate is 10cm or more. 

The obstetric conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis. Normally, it is 10 cm or more. 

The diagonal conjugate measures 12cm and the true conjugate measures 11cm.

Clinically, only the diagonal conjugate is assessed by measuring the distance between the base of the examiner's fingers and the fingertip touching the sacral promontory.  This determines the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory. The obstetric conjugate is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate. 

Note: Overt diabetes can cause fetal macrosomia during pregnancy. Thus, it may lead to cephalopelvic disproportion.

Given below is an image of the lateral plane in CT pelvimetry, showing the anteroposterior diameters of the pelvis. Line no. 4 is the obstetric conjugate and line no. 5 is the pelvic outlet.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely cause of lesion in the spine in young?
questions.solution:
Metastasis and multiple myeloma are the commonest causes of lesion in spine in individuals more than 40 years of age.

Causes of lesion in the spine in young:

  • Histiocytosis
  • Hemangioma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Osteoblastoma
  • Aneurysmal Bone cyst

questions.text: What is Zasko’s phenomenon related to?
questions.solution:
Zasko’s phenomenon/ tendon reaction is related to muscular changes following death.

It is elicited in the quadriceps femoris muscle. Striking the lower third of the muscle about 10 cms above the patella with a reflex hammer causes upward movement of the patella due to contraction of the muscle. It can be seen 1 to 2 hours after death.

questions.text: Which of the following is the biomedical concept of disease based upon?

choices.text: Combination of social, economic and political influences

questions.solution:
The biomedical concept of disease is based on the germ theory of disease, which was postulated by Louis Pasteur.

The germ theory of disease states that microorganisms known as pathogens or germs can lead to disease. It was criticized that it did not include environmental, social, psychological, and cultural determinants of health.  

The ecological concept of disease states that disease is the maladjustment of the human organism to the environment.

The psychosocial concept of disease hypothesised that health is also influenced by social, psychological, cultural and economic factors as well.

The holistic concept of disease includes all the above concepts to describe health.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after suffering a head injury in a road traffic accident. CT revealed a skull base fracture. The fracture line extended along the apex of the petrous bone involving the Dorello's canal. Which of the following cranial nerves is susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
The abducens nerve forms the content of Dorello's canal and hence is susceptible to injury in this case.

Dorello's canal is located at the petrous apex of the temporal bone and is formed by the petrosphenoidal/petroclinoid/Gruber's ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common sinusitis in children?
questions.solution:
The ethmoid sinus is the most common sinus involved in pediatric sinusitis.

It usually occurs when the infection spreads through the lamina papyracea.

questions.text: Results of various studies carried out to study the role of smoking in breast cancer are plotted below. Identify the plot.
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a forest plot used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis.

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the expansion of cholesteatoma and destruction of bone?

choices.text: Release of enzymes like collagenase and acid phosphatase at the site of destruction
Destruction of bone mediated by pressure necrosis
Osteoclasts and mononuclear infiltrates play a role in bone destruction
Erosion of ossicles is more common in children compared to adults

questions.solution:
Cholesteatoma does not cause bone destruction by pressure necrosis.

Bone destruction by cholesteatoma has been attributed to enzymes liberated by osteoclasts and mononuclear inflammatory cells such as:

  • Collagenase
  • Acid phosphatase and
  • Proteolytic enzymes.

Pediatric cholesteatoma (PC) has more inflammation and greater chances of ossicular erosion compared to adults. However, PC has lesser chances of petrous labyrinth invasion and lateral semicircular canal fistula formation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of cubital fossa?
questions.solution:
Bicipital aponeurosis is not a content, it forms the roof of cubital fossa. Biceps tendon is a content of cubital fossa.

Note - The Radial nerve is given as content of the cubital fossa in some books, in others, it's excluded as a content of cubital fossa due to its extreme lateral position.

Historically, when blood-letting was practiced, the bicipital aponeurosis was known as the "grace of God" tendon as it protected important contents of the fossa (i.e. the brachial artery and the median nerve).

questions.text: Which method is most appropriate when suitable land for waste disposal is available?
questions.solution:
Controlled tipping is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal when suitable land is available.

In this method, waste materials are placed in a trench, compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the day. This method is also called a sanitary landfill. Chemical, bacteriological and physical changes occur in the buried refuse with temperatures rising to over 60 degrees Celsius within 7 days.

Methods used for controlled tipping are:

  • Trench method
  • Ramp method
  • Area method

Sewage farming is also a method of sewage disposal in places where sufficient and suitable land is available. It is also called land treatment or broad irrigation.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby was brought with severe diaper rash. The parents gave a history of recurrent infections in the past 4 months which required frequent hospitalization.  On examination white patches were present in oral mucosa which could be scraped easily. The biopsy of the thymus showed remnants of Hassall's corpuscles. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is due to defect only in cell mediated immune response
B cell count can be normal

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). The biopsy of the thymus showing remnants of Hassall's corpuscles indicates it is due to adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency. SCID is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Usually the defect lies in the T-cell compartment with secondary impairment in humoral immunity.

Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive. Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including: 

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

There are 2 types of SCID based on inheritance:

1. X-linked SCID is the most common form and hence it is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect is the mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. T-cell numbers are greatly reduced, and although B cells may be normal in number, antibody synthesis is impaired because of the lack of T-cell help. The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

2. Autosomal recessive is most commonly caused due to deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA). The deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP). They are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes.

In the two most common forms (γc mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells. In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

Note: X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with burning pain and numbness in his hands, heat intolerance and decreased visual acuity. Further evaluation reveals skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Burning pain and numbness in hands, heat intolerance, decreased visual acuity with skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function is suggestive of Fabry’s disease which is inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder.

Fabry’s disease is a lipid storage disorder due to a deficiency of α-galactosidase A, resulting in the accumulation of globotriaosyl-ceramide in tissues. Young boys present with Fabry crises (burning pain in the hands, feet and proximal extremities), angiokeratomas (reddish blue telangiectatic skin lesions between the umbilicus and knees), corneal and lenticular opacities, renal failure and cardiomyopathy.

Note: All sphingolipidoses are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except Fabry’s disease.

Most of the common metabolic disorders are autosomal recessive disorders, except:

1. Autosomal dominant disorders:

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia

2. X-linked recessive disorders:

  • Hunter syndrome
  • Fabry disease
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
  • OTC deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies would you suspect in a patient with acute retrobulbar neuritis?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause acute retrobulbar neuritis.

Nutritional optic neuropathy is characterized by bilateral, symmetric, cecocentral scotomas and disturbance of color vision. Fundus morphology is usually normal. 

Deficiencies in the following vitamins are primarily responsible for the damage caused to the optic nerve: B1 (thiamine), B6 (pyridoxine), B9 (folic acid), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins are cofactors for many metabolic reactions and their deficiency leads to toxic byproduct accumulation within cells, which inhibits the electron transport chain and depresses mitochondrial function. Depletion of ATP leads to nerve dysfunction and eventual nerve death.

Chronic alcohol abuse is a commonly associated risk factor and a cause of malnourishment.

questions.text: Which of the following lesions does not arise from the terminal duct lobular unit of the breast?
questions.solution:
Periductal mastitis arises from the large lactiferous ducts.

It is also known as squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts, recurrent subareolar abscess, or Zuska disease.

The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU) is the basic functional and histopathological unit of the breast. Successive branching of large ducts eventually leads to the TDLU. Sclerosing adenosis, blue dome cyst, and carcinoma breast arise from the TDLU.

Related Pearl: Anatomic Origins of Common Breast Lesions

questions.text:
A 14-month-old baby was brought with complaints of refusal to walk after a minor fall while playing. Imaging revealed a left tibial fracture along with generalized sclerosis and a bone-in-bone appearance. Additionally, his developmental milestones were found to be delayed. Investigations are as follows. What is the likely renal tubular defect present in this patient?

Serum sodium - 137 mEq/L

Serum potassium - 2.9 mEq/L

Serum pH - 7.1

Serum bicarbonate - 15 mEq/L

Serum anion gap - 9

Urine pH - 5.7
questions.solution:
Pathological fractures and a bone-in-bone appearance point towards a diagnosis of osteopetrosis. The lab values are significant for hypokalemia with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. These findings are suggestive of renal tubular acidosis (RTA) type 3.

Type 3 or mixed RTA is a rare condition that usually occurs in neonates and infants. It is due to an autosomal recessive, inherited carbonic anhydrase-2 (CA-2) deficiency. This results in features of both distal and proximal RTA with:

  • Failure to reabsorb HCO3 at PCT
  • Failure to excrete H+ at DCT

This results in the following findings:

  • Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
  • Hypokalemia
  • Urinary pH > 5.5
  • Positive urine anion gap

As CA-2 is widely expressed, mutations of this gene result in a condition called marble brain disease or Guibaud-Vainsel syndrome. It presents with multiple clinical findings including: 

  • Cerebral calcifications
  • Mental retardation 
  • Mixed RTA (Type 3 RTA)
  • Osteopetrosis

questions.text: What is the concentration of bupivacaine you will use to provide labour analgesia, when used in combination with fentanyl?
questions.solution:
The concentration of bupivacaine used to provide labour analgesia, when used along with fentanyl is 0.0625%.

The required doses of local anaesthetics can be reduced if it is used in combination with opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil. 

Concentration of LA used in epidural:

Ropivacaine 0.2% 0.0625-0.2%

 

The dose of opioid used in epidural:

  • Fentanyl : 2–3 mcg/mL 
  • Sufentanil: 0.3–0.5 mcg/mL

questions.text: A patient has a spinal cord lesion at the level of L2 – L4 spinal nerve roots. All of the following may be seen in this patient, except:

choices.text: Paralysis of hip flexion and adduction

questions.solution:
Lesions at L2 – L4 spinal nerve roots do not cause paralysis of the knee flexors.

The paralysis of the flexion at the knee occurs due to the lesion at L5 – S1.

questions.text: A farmer presents with multiple discharging sinuses in the leg not responding to antibiotics. Most likely diagnosis is:-
questions.solution:
The causative agent here is madurella causing Eumycetoma

Mycetoma:-

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It is, therefore, commonly known as Maduramycosis or Madura foot. Mycetoma occurs worldwide.
  • Etiology:  It can be divided into three types, eumycetomas, actinomycetomas and botryomycosis.

Pathogenesis:-

  • Triad of symptoms: Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources, usually on thorns or splinters and results in tumefactions, deformities and draining sinuses discharging fungal colonies called grains or granules (triad of symptoms). 
  • Subcutaneous tissues of the feet, lower extremities, hands, and exposed areas are most often involved.
  • Grains: Within host tissues the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the color of which depends on the organism responsible.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • A. Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic.
  • B. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.

Treatment:-

The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a chronic history of smoking is diagnosed with small cell lung carcinoma. Which of the following statement is false regarding the management of the patient?

choices.text: In wedge resection, anatomical bronchopulmonary segment is removed.
Posterolateral thoracotomy approach is used for surgical resection.
Lobectomy is the treatment of choice for early-stage lung cancer.

questions.solution:
Wedge resection involves the non-anatomical excision of the tumor. Excision of the anatomical bronchopulmonary segment is called segmentectomy.

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a type of tumor that originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells) in the lining bronchial epithelium. They tend to metastasize early to lymph nodes and by the blood-borne spread. 

SCLC is very responsive to chemotherapy such that median survival may be doubled.

Surgery for lung cancers:

Surgery with curative intent is offered to patients with early-stage lung cancer (T1–3, N0–1). Lung cancer resection can be approached through:

  • Posterolateral thoracotomy
  • Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS)

Complications of surgery include:

  • Bleeding
  • Respiratory infection
  • Persistent air-leak
  • Bronchopleural fistula

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

questions.text: A young woman with uterine prolapse following pelvic trauma underwent a hysterectomy. A year later, she presents with vault prolapse. What would you not recommend for her?
questions.solution:
In a young patient with vault prolapse, ring pessary is not recommended.

Vault prolapse is managed as follows: 

  • If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacral suspension - The best method for vault prolapse.
  • If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation.
  • Laparoscopic colpopexy
  • If the patient does not want to retain sexual function:
    • Colpocleisis
    • Le Fort's repair 
  • Anterior colporrhaphy in case of cystocele
  • Posterior colporrhaphy in case of rectocele
  • If the patient is unfit for surgery, ring pessaries can be tried 
  • Posterior intravaginal slingplasty

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the antibodies of pernicious anaemia?

choices.text: Type I antibodies are found in both plasma and gastric juice
Type I antibody blocks the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor
Type II antibodies prevent the binding of the IF-B12 complex to ileal receptors
Type III antibodies are against haptocorrin

questions.solution:
Type III antibodies are not against haptocorrin. They recognize the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pumps.

Pernicious anaemia is a specific form of megaloblastic anaemia caused by autoimmune gastritis. It impairs the production of intrinsic factor, which is required for vitamin B12 uptake from the gut. 

Types of antibodies in pernicious anaemia are:

  • Type I antibodies - block the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor. They are found in both plasma and gastric juice
  • Type II antibodies - prevent binding of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 (IF-B12) complex to its ileal receptor
  • Type III antibodies - recognize the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump of parietal cells

questions.text: The most common site for chondrosarcoma is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common site for chondrosarcoma is the proximal femur.

Other sites of involvement are long bones of upper limbs > pelvis> the ribs.

questions.text: What is the average maternal requirement of iron during a singleton pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Maternal requirement of iron during a singleton gestation averages close to 1000 mg.

Iron requirement during pregnancy
Fetus and placenta 300 mg
Expansion of maternal hemoglobin mass 500 mg
Losses through normal excretion routes 200 mg
Total 1000 mg

The average iron stores in a non-pregnant female is around 300 mg. This falls short of the requirement of iron during pregnancy which is 1000 mg. Hence iron supplementation is necessary to prevent iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy. This also forms the basis for prophylactic iron supplementation during pregnancy.

Note: The Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (FOGSI) states that the iron requirement in pregnancy is 840 mg, as about 160 mg of iron is saved due to amenorrhea during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was found unconscious in her room by her husband. Beside her, he found an empty bottle of phenobarbital which she was prescribed for seizures. He rushed her to the ER. All of the following can be done to manage this case except:

choices.text: Alkaline diuresis to excrete the drug

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests barbiturate poisoning. Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist and has no effect on barbiturate toxicity. There is no antidote for barbiturate poisoning.

Management of barbiturate poisoning:

  • Maintain airway, breathing, circulation
  • Electrolyte balance
  • Gastric lavage
  • Alkaline diuresis by giving sodium bicarbonate
  • Hemodialysis in severe cases

Benzodiazepines have largely replaced barbiturates both medically and recreationally due to their wider therapeutic window. Despite the decline in barbiturate use, cases of acute poisoning with severe toxicity are still noted at staggering rates in developing countries, where the affordability of barbiturates lend to their increased use as anticonvulsants.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure?
questions.solution:
Hypertension is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure.

Left-sided heart failure can be divided into systolic and diastolic failure. Diastolic failure predominantly occurs in patients older than age 65 years. Here, the left ventricle is abnormally stiff and cannot relax during diastole.

Causes of diastolic heart failure:

  • Hypertension: most common 
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Bilateral renal artery stenosis 

Systolic failure is due to insufficient ejection fraction, i.e., pump failure. It occurs when the contractile function of the left ventricle is deranged.

questions.text: Naglazyme is used for treating patients with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.

Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome/MPS VI is caused by the deficiency of arylsulfatase B enzyme whose gene locus is on chromosome 5. Preservation of intelligence is the feature of this syndrome. It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, and contractures. 

Naglazyme is used as an enzyme replacement therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is false with respect to multiple hereditary exostoses?

choices.text: Affected genes are EXT1 and EXT2

questions.solution:
Multiple hereditary exostoses is associated with multiple osteochondromas. Multiple enchondromas are seen in Maffucci's syndrome and Ollier's disease.

Multiple hereditary exostoses is an autosomal dominant disease. The affected genes are EXT1 and EXT2 which are located on chromosomes 8 and 11 respectively.

There is an increased risk of malignant transformation of the osteochondromas in case of multiple lesions (about 5%). Solitary lesions have a 1% risk of malignant transformation.

The following X-ray image shows multiple osteochondromas around the knee.

questions.text: Which amongst the following is not a recommended treatment modality for treatment of osteoarthritis?
questions.solution:
Intra-articular hyaluronic acid (HA) injections are not recommended for the treatment of osteoarthritis.

Trials indicate that intraarticular HA has a small, clinically irrelevant benefit and is moreover associated with high costs and potential side effects such as pain flare-ups, etc. 

Joint excision, intrarticular injection of steroid and topical capsaicin are are recommended modalities of treatment.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the description of the term allodynia used in the context of pain management?

choices.text: Perception of ordinarily non-noxious stimulus as severe pain
pain in area that lacks sensation
Unpleasant sensation with or without a stimulus

questions.solution:
Perception of ordinarily non-noxious stimulus as severe pain is Allodynia.

Absence of pain perception: Analgesia

Pain in an area that lacks sensation: Anaesthesia Dolorosa

Unpleasant sensation with or without a stimulus: Dysesthesia

Related Pearl: Definitions in pain management

  • Allodynia- perception of ordinary non-noxious stimulus as pain
  • Analgesia- absence of pain perception
  • Anesthesia- absence of all sensation
  • Anesthesia Dolorosa- pain in area that lacks sensation
  • Dysesthesia-Unpleasant or abnormal sensation with or without a stimulus
  • Hypalgesia- diminished response to noxious stimulus
  • Hyperalgesia- increased response to noxious stimulation
  • Hyperesthesia- increased response to mild stimulation
  • Hyperpathia- presence of hyperesthesia, allodynia, hyperalgesia usually associated with over reaction, and persistence of the sensation after the stimulus
  • Hypoesthesia- reduced cutaneous sensation (e.g. light touch, pressure, temperature)
  • Neuralgia- pain in the distribution of nerve or a group of nerve
  • Paresthesia- Abnormal sensation perceived without an apparent stimulus
  • Radiculopathy- functional abnormality of one or more nerve root.

questions.text: Stranger anxiety develops at
questions.solution: Stranger anxiety develops at 7 months

questions.text: Skin scraping and KOH preparation shows an abundance of yeast like cells and short branched filaments. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The causative agent is lipophilic, yeast like fungus Malassezia furfur (Pityrosporum orbiculare).

Pityriasis versicolor is a chronic usually asymptomatic, involvement of the stratum corneum, characterized by discrete or confluent macular areas of discoloration or de-pigmentation of the skin.

The areas involved are mainly the chest, abdomen, upper limbs and back.

Skin scraping and KOH preparation shows an abundance of yeast like cells and short branched filaments (Sphagetti and meatball appearance).

questions.text: A primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation is admitted with preterm labour contractions. She was diagnosed with gestational diabetes, on screening. Which of the following tocolytic drugs should be avoided in her?
questions.solution:
Terbutaline should be avoided in pregnant women with diabetes.

Terbutaline (β-mimetic drugs) given for tocolysis can cause hyperglycemia, which can cause diabetic ketoacidosis. Factors precipitating ketoacidosis in pregnancy:

  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Infection
  • Non-compliance
  • Insulin pump failure
  • β-sympathomimetic drugs
  • Corticosteroids
  • Poor glycemic control

questions.text: A diabetic female patient on isoniazid and rifampicin for tuberculosis developed deep vein thrombosis. She was started on warfarin, but there was no elevation in prothrombin time. The next step should be?
questions.solution:
The next step should be using low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

The anticoagulant effect of warfarin is assessed by the measurement of prothrombin time (PT). Failure of elevation of PT indicates the decreased effect of warfarin. If we increase the dose of warfarin, it will take 5 days to prevent DVT. For immediate action, heparin or LMWH has to be started.

LMWH has more inhibitory activity on factor Xa than on factor IIa due to the conformational changes in antithrombin caused by the short molecules of LMWH. This conformational change the rate of factor Xa inhibition. LMWH has little effect on platelets. Heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux are used in the treatment of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, unstable angina, or acute myocardial infarction. Some of the examples of LMWH preparations are enoxaparin and dalteparin. The major adverse effect is bleeding and there is a low incidence of thrombocytopenia.

Other options:

Option A- Effect of warfarin starts in 4-5 days. Therefore, heparin or LMWH has to be started for immediate effect.

Option B- Acenocoumarin is also an oral anticoagulant. Its metabolism is also subjected to induction by rifampicin.

Option C- Rifampicin is an enzyme inducer and can decrease the effect of warfarin. Rifampicin is the most effective drug for tuberculosis and should not be replaced.

questions.text: The CT scan of a patient who presented with deteriorating consciousness is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image demonstrates the Mount Fuji sign, a specific radiological finding of tension pneumocephalus.

This sign is characterised by bilateral compression and separation of the frontal lobes due to the trapped subdural and interhemispheric free air, which appears as non-attenuating collections resembling the peak of Mount Fuji. 

Tension pneumocephalus is a rare, life-threatening condition most commonly caused by traumatic head injury. Other causes include skull base fractures, neurosurgical procedures, infections (meningitis, encephalitis, or brain abscess), brain tumours, or the use of nitrous oxide during anaesthesia. 

The mass effect exerted by the subdural air compresses the underlying brain parenchyma, often resulting from a ball-valve mechanism causing one-way air entry into the subdural space. This raises intracranial pressure (ICP), distinguishing it from non-tension pneumocephalus, which lacks significant mass effect or raised ICP. 

The elevated ICP leads to rapid clinical deterioration, such as worsening consciousness, necessitating urgent neurosurgical intervention to decompress the trapped air and prevent permanent brain damage.

questions.text: A factory worker presents to the clinic with fever, tiredness, and a chronic dry cough. He says his symptoms are worst on the first day of the week, improve by the end of the week, and are almost non-existent over the weekends. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above characteristic pattern of symptoms is called Monday fever or Monday chest tightness and is due to byssinosis. 

Byssinosis is seen commonly in cotton factory workers due to cotton dust exposure. It is also caused due to flax, hemp, and jute dust.

It is due to occupational hypersensitivity reaction with symptoms occurring (or recurring) on the first day of the workweek and diminishing by the weekend due to development of tolerance.

questions.text: Which organization does the image given below stand for?

choices.text: National Programme for Control of Blindness
National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment

questions.solution: The symbol stands for National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI), which was previously called the National Programme for Control of Blindness.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause osteomalacia?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D deficiency in adults leads to defective mineralisation leading to osteomalacia.

This has insidious course and the patients complain of bone pain, back pain and muscle weakness

Various drugs which cause Osteomalacia

Anticonvulsants, and rifampicin

Increased metabolism (loss of vitamin D)

Cholestyramine

Impaired absorption (decrease entero hepatic circulation)

Isoniazid

Impaired 25 hydroxylation

Ketoconazole

Impaired 1, alpha hydroxylation

Phosphate binding antacids,

Interfere with renal phosphates absorption

Etidronate, fluoride , heavy metal, aluminium

Impaired mineralization and cause mineralization defect if not frank Osteomalacia

Steroids do not cause osteomalacia but they cause osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true?

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
It is protective against H.pylori infection
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.solution:
Generalized pruritus seen in polycythemia vera (PV) is a consequence of the activation of mast cells by JAK 2 mutation.

Other options:

Option A: The risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with erythrocytosis, not the degree of thrombocytosis.

Option C: In polycythemia vera, there is an increased risk of H.pylori infection.

Option D: Thrombosis is the major cause of mortality in polycythemia vera. The incidence of acute leukemia in patients not exposed to chemotherapy or radiation therapy is low.

PV is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which red cells, granulocytes & platelets accumulate in the absence of a physiological stimulus. The most common mutation seen in PV is the JAK2 mutation.

Clinical features of polycythemia vera are:

  • Thrombosis is the most common manifestation and is the major cause of mortality. Uncontrolled erythrocytosis causes increased viscosity of the blood causing thrombosis of the vessels. Patients may present with stroke, transient ischemic attacks, myocardial infarction, and Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • Aquagenic pruritis is generalized itching following a warm bath or a shower due to increased mast cells and histamine.
  • Erythromelalgia is erythema and pain in the fingers, hands, and feet due to increased platelet stickiness.
  • Splenomegaly due to increased destruction of RBCs in the spleen
  • Gout is due to the excessive proliferation of the marrow cells leading to elevated uric acid levels.

questions.text: While reading a forensic report, you notice that the identification of the suspect was done through edgeoscopy. What does this method evaluate?

choices.text: Sweat pore openings on fingerprint ridges
Fissures and grooves on lip print

questions.solution:
Edgeoscopy is a method of identification through the examination of the unique details and characteristics found along the edges of individual fingerprint ridges. 

Methods of identification using different prints:

  • Dactylography - evaluation of finger prints
  • Poroscopy - evaluation of sweat pore openings on fingerprint ridges
  • Cheiloscopy - evaluation of lip prints
  • Podography - evaluation of foot prints
  • Rugoscopy - evaluation of palatal rugae
  • Ridgeology - evaluation of friction ridges on fingerprints

Note: Locard is known as the father of poroscopy, edgeoscopy and ridgeology.

questions.text: After detailed neuropsychiatric evaluation, an ICU patient was found to have severe retrograde amnesia with largely preserved anterograde memory. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Severe retrograde amnesia with minimal or no anterograde amnesia is seen in post-traumatic stress disorder. It is referred to as dissociative/psychogenic amnesia. It is also known as hysterical amnesia or functional amnesia.

Psychogenic amnesia presents with a sudden onset of:

  • Extensive and severe retrograde amnesia
  • A loss of personal identity - unable to recall their own name, information from childhood, or from their past.
  • Minimal anterograde amnesia

The other given options can all cause both retrograde and anterograde amnesia.

questions.text: Each value of a study sample is multiplied by 10. What would be the new standard deviation of the observations?
questions.solution:
When each element of a sample is multiplied by 10, the new standard deviation= 10 x original standard deviation.

The formula for standard deviation, SD = √∑(x - x̄)2/n-1.

If each element of the distribution is multiplied by 10, the new mean will become 10 times the original mean.

If all observations are multiplied by 10, then the new SD = √∑(10x-10x̄)2/n-1

= 10 √∑(x - x̄)2/n-1

= 10 x Original SD

Change in variance: variance = square of standard deviation, so when SD becomes 10 times, 

the variance will be  10² = 100 times the original variance.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: The prevalence of the disease 'X' in a population is 30%. The diagnostic test for this disease has a specificity of 0.80 and a sensitivity of 0.90. What is the negative predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The negative predictive value of the above test is 95%.

For convenience, let us assume that the total population in this scenario is 100.

The prevalence of the disease is 30%. So the total number of people with the disease is 30(TP+FN) and disease-free(FP+TN) is 70.

Since sensitivity is 0.90, i.e. TP/(TP + FN) = 90%.

The total true positives (TP) = 90/100 x (TP+FN) = 90/100 x 30 = 27

False-negative(FN) = 30-27 = 3

Since specificity is 0.80, i.e. TN/(FP+TN) = 80%.

Total true negatives (TN) =(FP+TN) x 80/100 = 70 x 80/100 = 56

False-positive(FP) = 70-56 = 14

The given data is represented below:

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

27 (TP)

14 (FP)

41

Test -

3 (FN)

56 (TN)

59

Total

30(TP+FN)

70(FP+TN) 

100

Negative predictive value (NPV) = TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = 56/59 = 0.949 = 95%.

An alternate formula(Bayes theorem) that can be used is NPV = (1-P) x Sp /[P x (1-Sn)] +[(1-P) x Sp]

Sn- Sensitivity, P- Prevalence, Sp- Specificity

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding adenocarcinoma of the cervix.

choices.text: Most common site is transformation zone
Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer among women in India

questions.solution:
The most common site of adenocarcinoma is endocervix.

It commonly occurs in young females and OCP users, and is associated with HPV 18.

questions.text: Which of the following is not secreted by T-helper type 2 cells?
questions.solution:
TH2 cells secrete IL­4, IL­5, and IL­13.

Three subsets of CD4+ T cells secrete different types of cytokines and elicit different types of inflammation.

questions.text: A term infant develops jaundice at day 2 of life. It first appeared on the sclera and progressed to the trunk by day 4. It completely disappeared by day 7 following phototherapy. Which of the following statements is false regarding the cause of this pattern of jaundice?

choices.text: Due to a rise in unconjugated bilirubin
Due to limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver
Due to Rh incompatibility between maternal and fetal red blood cells
Due to increased breakdown of fetal red blood cells

questions.solution:
The above pattern of jaundice is suggestive of physiological jaundice/icterus neonatorum. It is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver.

It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd day, usually peaks on the 4th day at 5–6 mg/dL, and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth.

Rh incompatibility between maternal and fetal red blood cells leads to pathological jaundice.

 

Note:  

Depth of jaundice (degree of yellowness) should be carefully noted (light staining as lemon-yellow; deep staining as orange-yellow), as it is an important indicator of the level of jaundice. Earlier, the involvement of soles and palms indicated severe jaundice but deep yellow staining (even in absence of yellow soles or palms) may be associated with severe jaundice.

questions.text: The ligament that maintains anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
The round ligament helps maintain the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy. 

However, the anteversion in the non-pregnant uterus is maintained by both the uterosacral ligament and round ligament.

Anteflexion of uterus is at the level of internal os. 

Angle of anteversion Angle of anteflexion
Angle between the cervix and vagina Angle between cervix and uterus
90o 120o

(Mnemonic - V for version, V for vagina)

The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion.

In anteversion, the external os is directed downward and backward, so that on vaginal examination, the fingers find that the lowest part of the cervix is the anterior lip.

When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forward, and the lowest part of the cervix is either the external os or its posterior lip.

 

Related Pearl: Supports of the uterus

A. Primary supports

  • Muscular or active support of the uterus:
    • Pelvic diaphragm
    • Perineal body
    • Urogenital diaphragm
  • Ligamentous (fibromuscular or mechanical) support:
    • Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt or cardinal ligament
    • Uterosacral ligament
    • Round ligament of the uterus
    • Pubocervical ligament
    • Uterine axis

B. Secondary supports formed by peritoneal ligaments:

  • Broad ligament
  • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
  • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text: What is the angle at which the letters in Snellen’s chart subtend on the nodal point of eye?
questions.solution:
At the given distance, each letter subtends an angle of 5 min at the nodal point of the eye

Snellen’s chart is used for distant vision.

The patient should read the chart at a distance of 6 m.

The image below shows Snellen's chart.

questions.text: When treating an anemic patient with a history of inflammatory bowel disease, which of the following iron formulations will you prefer?
questions.solution:
In an anemic patient with IBD, parenteral iron is preferred over oral formulations. The parenteral formulation of iron among the given options is ferrous sucrose.

On intravenous administration, it is taken up by reticuloendothelial cells where it dissociates and iron is utilized.

The formulations used for parenteral iron therapy are:

  • Iron dextran
  • Iron - sorbitol - citric acid
  • Ferrous sucrose
  • Ferric carboxy maltose

Ferrous sulfate, ferrous gluconate, and ferrous fumarate are oral iron preparations. 

The FDA, in 2019, approved oral ferric maltol (30mg BD) for the treatment of iron deficiency anemia in adults. It is a non-salt-based iron preparation with fewer gastrointestinal side effects.

questions.text: “Proof of concept” for a new drug is generally proven in which phase of a clinical trial?
questions.solution:
“Proof of concept” for a new drug is generally proven in phase II of a clinical trial.

Phase II of clinical trials

  • It involves a small group of patients (50-500).
  • Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease.
  • The study is designed to obtain "Proof of concept"(Potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase III studies).

 

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Phase I

(First in human)

(First in patient)

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

10 – 100 

50 - 500

Large or according to study

questions.text: Which of the following types of morbidly adherent placenta is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows placenta increta. 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be:

  • Total - involving all lobules of the placenta 
  • Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

questions.text: A previously untreated HIV-positive patient is diagnosed with tuberculosis and treatment is initiated for both the diseases. Two weeks into treatment, he suddenly complains of high fever, severe malaise and worsening cough. What is the likely explanation?

choices.text: Bacterial endotoxin release due to death of TB bacilli

questions.solution:
Concurrent treatment with anti-retroviral therapy is the most likely explanation in this case resulting in Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS). Its characteristics are:

  • Temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms (lymphadenopathy, fever or worsening of pulmonary infiltrations, pleural effusion) and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ART. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT. 
  • It is seen weeks to months following the initiation of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART).
  • It is most common in previously untreated patients starting therapy with a CD4+ T cell count <50/μL who experience a sudden drop in viral load.
  • The earlier ART is started and the lower the baseline CD4+ T-cell count, the greater the risk of IRIS.
  • In severe cases, the use of immunosuppressive drugs such as glucocorticoids may be required to blunt the inflammatory component of IRIS while specific antimicrobial therapy takes effect.

Note: Hypersensitivity to isoniazid is extremely rare and the presentation includes maculopapular rash.

questions.text: An elderly man, with congestive cardiac failure, complains of shortness of breath when lying down. What is the mechanism behind this symptom?

choices.text: Reservoir function of veins in lower limbs.

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes orthopnea in congestive heart failure. It is due to reservoir function of pulmonary veins.

Orthopnea is dyspnea occurring in the recumbent position.

It results from redistribution of fluid from the splanchnic circulation and lower extremities (increased venous return) into the heart during recumbency. This increased venous return is not put out by the left ventricle and hence pools in the pulmonary veins that acts as capacitance vessels (reservoir function) adding to the already congested pulmonary vasculature resulting in breathing difficulty.

questions.text: You can advise any of the following tests for screening of a patient suspected to be having Cushing's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Determination of plasma ACTH levels is not advised as a screening test for a patient with Cushing's syndrome.

Plasma ACTH determination is done to distinguish between ACTH-dependent and independent causes. It is done after the screening or confirmation of Cushing's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: Ejection fraction is
questions.solution:
Ejection fraction is SV/EDV.
The amount of blood ejected by each ventricle per stroke at rest is 70–90 mL. The end-diastolic ventricular volume is about 130 mL. The ejection fraction is the percentage of the end-diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke, is about 65%.

questions.text: The lactose operon is likely to be transcribed when ______

choices.text: There is more glucose in the cell than lactose
There is glucose but no lactose in the cell
Cyclic AMP and lactose levels are both high within the cell

questions.solution:
The lac operon is induced only when cyclic AMP and lactose levels are both high within the cell.

When lactose is present in abundance, a small amount of lactose is converted to allolactose. This compound binds to the repressor protein of the lac operon and creates a conformational change. As a result, the repressor cannot bind to the operator and transcription of the structural genes occurs. This is an example of negative regulation.

This can only occur when glucose is absent. In the absence of glucose, adenylyl cyclase is active. This generates sufficient quantities of cAMP which bind to catabolite activator protein (CAP).The cAMP–CAP trans-acting complex binds to the CAP-binding site, another regulatory region present upstream of the structural genes of the operon. This causes RNA polymerase to more efficiently initiate transcription at the promoter site. This is an example of positive regulation.

questions.text: Which of the following images depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The USG in image 2 depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. It is identified by the T sign.

In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the intervening membrane has only 2 layers (i.e) 2 amnions. This thin membrane is seen ending at the common placenta giving rise to the T sign. 

Sonographic assessment of monochorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Single placental mass
  • Presence of intervening membrane - T sign
  • Thin intervening membrane <2mm

The best time of delivery of monochorionic diamniotic twins is 34 - 37weeks + 6 days.

Image 1: Dichorionic twins with twin peak or lambda sign

Image 3: Monochorionic monoamniotic twins with no intervening membranes between them

Image 4: Triplets with 3 separate gestational sacs

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for a recent eye injury. The result of his Placido disc test is shown below. What is the correct interpretation?
questions.solution:
The given Placido’s disc test result indicates a normal corneal surface.

This test is used to detect an abnormal corneal surface. Irregularities of the corneal surface cause distortion of the circles.

Distortion of the circle is seen in keratoconus, keratoglobus, corneal ulcer, and corneal abrasion.

questions.text: Metachromatic granules are seen in:-
questions.solution:
Metachromatic granules/BabeErnest’s granules/ Volutin granules:-

  • These granules, which are the accumulation of polymerized phosphates, are responsible for the beaded appearance of the bacteria. 
  • The granules can be demonstrated by special staining techniques, such as Albert stain, Neisser stain, and Ponder stain.
  • Their main function is to supply phosphate for nucleic acid synthesis, cell division, energy metabolism and as a source of phosphorous for nutrition.

Metachromic granules are seen in:-

  • Corynebacterium
  • Spirillum
  • Rhizobium
  • Bacillus
  • Gardenella vaginalis
  • Bordetella pertusis

Albert staining: Metachromic granules appear bluish black whereas the body of bacilli appear green or bluish green

questions.text: A patient recently returned from sub-Saharan Africa presents with painless haematuria. This structure was found on microscopy of urine. It was measured at 125 micrometers in length. Identify this structure.
questions.solution:
This is an egg of Schistosoma haematobium, recognised by its characteristic size (110-170 micrometers in length), internal miracidia and terminal spine.

The terminal spine differentiates it from Schistosoma mansoni and Schistosoma japonicum.

Schistosoma haematobium primarily causes genito-urinary schistosomiasis.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a Gram negative fusiform gliding bacillus?
questions.solution:
Capnocytophaga are fusiform or filamentous gram negative coccobacilli.

They are part of human oral flora, occasionally cause periodontal disease and sepsis in immunocompromised hosts.

questions.text: A patient who comes with a history of an insect bite while trekking is diagnosed to have scrub typhus. The weil-Felix reaction will show positivity for which of the following antigens?
questions.solution:
The Weil–Felix reaction for scrub typhus shows positivity for OX K.

Weil–Felix test is a heterologous agglutination test used for the diagnosis of rickettsial infections. The test detects anti-rickettsial antibodies that cross-react with O antigens of certain nonmotile strains of Proteus. In this test, nonmotile strains of Proteus vulgaris OX 19 and OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K are used as antigens. The Weil–Felix test becomes positive 10–20 days after infection.

  • Sera from epidemic typhus shows a strong reaction with OX 19 antigen and weakly agglutinates with OX 2 antigen. 
  • Sera from endemic typhus shows a strong reaction with OX 19 antigen and may weakly agglutinate with OX 2 antigen. 
  • Sera from scrub typhus agglutinates with OX K antigen.
  • Weil–Felix test is negative or weakly reactive in Brill–Zinsser disease.

Weil–Felix test in rickettsial diseases:

Rickettsial diseases   Agglutination  
  OX 19 OX 2 OX K
Epidemic typhus +++ +  -
Brill–Zinsser disease +/-  -  -
Endemic typhus +++ +/-  -
Spotted fever ++ ++  -
Scrub typhus  -  - +++

questions.text: An 8-year-old child diagnosed to have focal seizures was initiated on oxcarbazepine. Which of the following would be incorrect regarding the agent being used?

choices.text: Enzyme induction potency is less when compared to carbamazepine
Hyponatremia risk is less when compared to carbamazepine

questions.solution:
The risk of hyponatremia with oxcarbazepine is higher when compared to carbamazepine. 

Option A: Oxcarbazepine is a keto analog of carbamazepine. It is a prodrug. The mechanism of action of oxcarbazepine is by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels (same as carbamazepine).

Option C: Active form is metabolized by glucuronide conjugation.

Option B: Oxcarbazepine does not cause auto-induction of metabolizing enzymes. It can induce CYP enzymes but less potent when compared to carbamazepine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient complained of excessive daytime sleepiness and tiredness throughout the day. He also had episodes where he felt losing his strength in his muscles and falling to the ground, especially when he is stressed or laughing. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of narcolepsy. The finding mentioned here is called cataplexy. It is a sudden, brief loss of voluntary muscle tone, with partial or no loss of consciousness. It is triggered by strong emotions such as laughter or stress, commonly associated with narcolepsy. 

Narcolepsy is a type of hypersomnolence disorder. Symptoms commonly appear in the second decade of life. A characterized by a tetrad of symptoms is seen:

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness where there are recurrent episodes of irrepressible sleepiness occurring in a day for more than 3 months. 
  2. Cataplexy- It is associated with deficiency of the neurotransmitter hypocretin. Sudden loss of muscle tone may lead to jaw drop, head drop, weakness of the knees, paralysis of skeletal muscles, or collapse. 
  3. Sleep paralysis is where patients report being unable to move their muscles while waking up in the morning, even though they are conscious and awake. 
  4. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations where auditory or visual hallucinations are vivid, dream-like, occurring at the onset of sleep or while waking up and cause frightening for a brief period of time. 

Occurrence of REM sleep within 10 minutes of sleep onset (sleep-onset REM periods) is also seen in these patients. 

Modafinil, an a1-adrenergic receptor agonist, is used to reduce the number of sleep attacks and improve psychomotor performance. Besides this, tricyclic antidepressants or SSRIs are found effective in eliminating cataplexy. Psychosocial therapy like sched­uled naps, lifestyle adjustment, counseling, etc can also be employed. 

Other options:

Option A- Catalepsy, also known as waxy flexibility is a condition in which a person maintains abnormal body posi­tions for very long durations. This is seen in severe cases of catatonic schizophrenia.

Option C- Gegenhalten or paratonic rigidity is seen in frontal lobe lesions. It leads to an involuntary increase in resistance to passive movements.  

Option D- Negativism is when a person opposes or resists any effort to be moved or does the opposite of what is asked. They are seen in catatonic schizophrenia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the DSM-5 group somatic symptoms and related disorders?
questions.solution:
Dissociative disorder is classified separately under DSM-5.

The somatic symptoms and related disorders group in DSM-5 includes:

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either false labor pain or prolonged latent phase. The appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.

False labor can be differentiated from the latent phase of labor by therapeutic rest i.e., the patient is sedated with morphine.

Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest continue to be in prolonged latent phase.

There is no indication of cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is present. Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phase.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features can be seen in a patient presenting with accidental haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Abruptio placenta is also known as accidental haemorrhage or premature separation of placenta. Tender uterus is seen in abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placenta is defined as premature separation of a normally situated placenta. It is of the following types:

  • Concealed
  • Revealed
  • Mixed

Shock may be pronounced which may be out of proportion to visible bleeding.

Uterine height

Proportionate to the period of gestation

Maybe disproportionately enlarged

FHS

Usually absent

 In mixed type, features of concealed variety will be predominant.
